div.head: THE STATIONER TO THE READER.
div.p:
AMong the many Publick Benefits wherein these Times are happier than the former Ages, I presume, it pleases you to see the Improvement of the Stage. Playes are now acted that delight Spectators, without Immodesty, or Prophanenesse: two rocks, on which heretofore divers excellent Authours
split themselves, and cast such an odium upon drammatick Presentments, that the best persons shun'd them, as the worst of recreations. Whereas our Theatres (reformed, as well as beautified) are by all frequented, as the great Schools of Moral Virtue. But I have brought you to the House, 'tis not good manners to keep you at door; be pleased to enter, and accept of this Impression, from

div.head: THE PROLOGUE TO THE KING, At the COCKPIT at White-Hall.
div.l: SIR, by the humble Writer I am sent
To move you in a Suit by President,
That you will please, like Charles the 5 th, to lay
Aside (this Night) the Business of the Day,
And look upon slight Images, far short
Of those presented in that Emp'rour's Court;
For, Art does not our Powr so far inlarge,
That we can make two wooden armies charge,
Or a carv'd Sparrow fly: but we do bring
A Nightingale, sweet Philomel to sing:
And from old Verulam ('mong Time's Decayes
Shrunk to a name) th' Inhabitants we raise,
Who if in their new life they may invite
The best of Caesars to the least Delight,
To th Authour 'twill be such a Ioy, as none
Conceive, but only those You smile upon,

div.head: THE PROLOGUE To the STAGE.
div.l: WHat's here? so many Noble Persons met?
Nay then I see, this House will not be let,
Which by our Friends (from all parts of the Nation)
Is so well warm'd after the long Vacation,
Believe me, Ladies, the pure Country-air
Has made you fresh-complexion'd; and our Care
Shall be (whil'st you'r in London) to expell
Care from your hearts, that you may still look well.
Gentlemen, when we lay becalm'd, you wa'k'd
Over the pleasant Meades, bowl'd, hunted, hawk'd,
And having exercis'd your Bodies thus,
To recreate your Minds, you come to Us.
Never were Friends more welcome— if I may
Be bold to bid you welcome to a Play
Of your own making; I confess, 'tis writ
By th' Authour of The Slighted Maid, and yet
You'r th' Authours of it: for I heard him say,
When you encourag'd that, you made this Play.
And now, since to your selves your title's known,
We hope, you'l have a kindness for your Own.

div.head: THE STEP-MOTHER: A Tragi-Comedy.
Actus Primus.
div.stage: Enter Filamor and Fromund in a Garden, Tetrick walking alone, and reading.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: NO, Fromund, I have had too many proofs
Of thy Fidelity, to doubt it now.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Sir, if you were not Filamor, nor Son
To my Prince, if I were not your sworn Servant;
Without relation, meerly for your Virtues,
Fromund would sacrifice his life to serve you
In this Design against your Step-Mother,
Your envious and imperious Step-Mother,
Who rules your Father, and would ruine You.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: The difficulty of the work will be,
When we have got my Father to the Woods,
How we shall keep him there: for since he marry'd
This Woman, she has master'd both his Courage
And Reason; she governs his very Soul,
He cannot live without her.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: There's the man
Whose pow'r can ballance hers, for your Old Father
Dotes but on two, his Wife and that great Scholar
My Friend.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: And you can make him ours.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Not I,
What I am to present him from your Highness
Will make him Yours.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: If he once ingages
Nothing can alter him, he's an honest man:
Peevish, but (to our comfort) Covetous:
Yet he'l not take a Bribe to do unjustly;
But if he be imploy'd, he will be pay'd,
This Gold and this rich Book will sweeten him.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Attacque him; I wait for my severe Mistress,
'Tis Princess Caesarina's walking-time.

div.stage: Fromund claps Tetrick on the Back.

sp.speaker: Tetrick.
sp.p: The Prince's Tutor? Well return'd to Britain.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Our good old Master's Favorite, learn'd Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Out of what Region have the Clowds drop:
Fromund?
Where all this while wert thou and our young Prince?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: We liv'd where Grapes grow, like our Crabs, in
hedges,
Where every Tree looks lovelier then this Garden,
In Italy, the Paradise of Nature

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: The plague of War consume your Paradise;
The Galls over-run Italy again;
Ten thousand Dropsies, Cramps and Gouts torment
That leg of earth.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Men may well snarle when they are us'd like Dogs,
As we have been, by our Italian Masters.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: But now the Roman Legions are call'd back,
And we are free-men, Britain is old Britain.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: But Italy is still curs'd Italy,
I would not hear thee praise it any more,
For twenty pieces of Imperial Gold.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: I'l try what pow'r one piece has over you. aside.
This Medall (Caesar grav'd in gold) I brought
From Rome for thee: and is not Italy
(Where these Flowers grow) a most delicious Country?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: The Garden of the World! how blind was I,
That could not see the Beauty of Italy
Till I had wip'd my eyes with Caesar's Picture;
Now I perceive the errour of my Judgment;
Why should we hate Countries that hurt not us?
The Roman Yoke galls not our necks: you see
Our old Lord, Prince of Verulam, dares own
His Title: and what Curiosities
Has our young Prince brought from the Nursery
Of Arms and Arts, sweet Italy?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Rare Musique;
And Voices, such a Trebble and a Base—

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: How merrily shall we live— pox o' the devill.
sp.stage: Pontia, Caesarina, and Brianella walk over the Stage.
sp.l: There's the confoundress of thy Master's musique,
Pluto could not have rak'd him out of hell
Such a Step-Mother, she reigns o're his Father.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: But the date of her Sovereign pow'r is out,
By this time the old Prince is in our hands,
We have him in the Woods.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: And long you'l keep him;
His very first reflexion on the fury
Or flattery of's Wife, posts him to Court,
He'l leave you.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: 'Tis expected; therefore, Tetrick,
My Master has sent me to ingage you,
If th'old Prince change his mind, you can perswade him,
He believes all you say.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: I believe nothing
You say, or do; your Plot's a scurvy Plot.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: But you can mold it into a better form.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Nay, since you can begin your plots without me,
End e'm without me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: And shall I return
The Prince this answer?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Shall I return his Princely Present too?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: That is to be consider'd of— let's fee't.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Alas, 'Tis only a poor Table-Book,
The cover is but Gold and set with Rubies,
Not worth your looking on

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: This needed not;
Without fee, I'd have been o'th' Prince's Counsel,
And the Cause shall go with him, never fear 't;
But they say, the Step-mother's inquiring
For Witches, they'l discover all we do.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: That she may seek no further, I have told
Her Favorite, my Mistriss Brianella,
That yesternight there came into the Woods
A Bard, that's a Witch-maker:

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Your Witch-maker
By any means must be attended by
A Conjurer and a Witch to learn their Trades.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I'l be the Witch, I think my face will serve;

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: And Schollars make rare Conjurers, I'l play my part,
Come, bring me now to kisse your Masters hand.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: Stir Caesarina, only exercise,
Can prevent th' undermining of thy Colour
By the Green Sickness, that long gravel walk
Did alwayes please thee.

sp.speaker: Caesarina.
sp.l: When I was in breath,
But I'm grown too short-winded for a walk
Of this length, Madam, I shall ne'r hold out.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: One quarter of an hour, and I'l release thee.
But Brianella, art thou sure thou saw'st
Filamor in the Arbor?

sp.speaker: Brianella.
sp.l: At this Lute;
With him a Flamen, and a winged Boy
That should be Cupid, perhaps Priest and God
Will in some Dialogue present themselves
To Princesse Caesarina; the Prince said,
They should sing the Description of a Triumph.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Then I shall now see whether Filamor
Continue still his Love to Caesarina,
And how she looks on him after his Travails;
Lets to the close walk, my Son Adolph's there.

div.stage: Filamor discover'd in an Arbor, with a Lute in his hand; on either side the Arbor, on two pedestals, Cupid stands, and the Flamen kneels: as Caesarina walks by they sing.

sp.speaker: Flamen.
sp.l: Why unarm'd, poor Cupid, pr'y thee,
Tell a Mortal how tis with thee?

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: To one Mortal, what another
Has committed, may be told;
I am plunder'd, so's my Mother.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: What frail Man durst be so bold?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: No, to make us more inglorious,
Tis a Woman that's Victorious.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: They (who saw her)
Say, she rides in Triumph here,
That my Mother's white Doves draw her
In their Chariot.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: By a sure Token,
Thy Torch quench'd, and thy Bow broken,
Makes her Trophie; Captives follow.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: One Slave Sorrow's Livery wears,
His Eyes sink, his Cheeks fall hollow,
In his Face his fate appears.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: That Slaves Filamon; no Lover
Caesarina triumphs over,
Suffers in Love's Cause so sadly,
Cupid help?

sp.speaker: Cup,
sp.l: I cannot do
Him a favour; I would gladly:
But I am her Captive too.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: If a Man have a passion,
He that hopes for a Cure,

div.stage: Enter above Pontia, Caesarina, Adolph, Brianella▪

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: Has Filamor been so long out of Britain,
To forget Caesarina is your Daughter?
Court her without your leave?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: That's more then you know (by your favour, Madam)

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Heav'n is in your Eyes,
Disorder not that beauty with a frown
On your Adorer; if my love displease,
Be not offended with my gratitude,
I name you in my Hymnes, as shipwrack't men
Sing to the Deities which have preserv'd them;
By virtue of that sacred word, your Name,
I have out-liv'd the pains of death in absence,
At my return to you, dearer then life,
Friends, Father, or our common Mother Britain;
Will you, for want of one poor smile, destroy me?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Make not your self a Supplicant to me,
Prince Filamor, kneel where you owe a Duty;
Kneel to the Gods, to grant you Understanding,
That you may see, I cannot love; and then
To one that can love you, apply your self;
You have my counsel and resolve.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: For pity,
Leave me not to despair; though all my sighs
Breath'd on the aire of Italy, were lost
At such a distance; now we'r met again;
May not pray'rs alter your severity?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: Can prayers alter a Decree of Fate?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Pray'rs joyn'd with services: if Verulam
Open too narrow a Prospect for your eye
I'l draw my sword, and merit from my Country
th'inlargement of our bounds.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: He works upon
The humours of Ambition; I'm afraid
The Milk she suckt from my Breast will betray her.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: To be the first on Mountains, in poor hovells,
Rather then t'have the second place in Rome,
Was Caesar's wish, but 'tis not Caesarina's;
Your Cottages cannot make me a Court;
I'm not like Ladies newly come to London,
Who from the vast height of Diana's Temple
Look down, and please their eyes with little people,
Objects, that are not magnify'd, I scorn;
The Prince that would discover his Dominions,
Let him turn the Prospective Glass to me
At the right End, great Subjects I must fee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For my friends sake, would she did yield.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Great Subjects! all our British Lords shall kneel
To Caesarina; I have form'd it thus,
You know the Kentish-men have took up arms
Against the Trinobants, the Londoners;
Whilst Scots and Borderers, with their deadly feuds,
Ingage the Northern parts in Civil Warr;
No sooner from the Roman Slavery
This Iland's free, but we (like mad-men arm'd)
Die our white-feather'd shafts in our own blood;
Against these Enemies to the Publick Peace
I'l make a League, and fight my Country's battails,
Till I fix Britain in a Settlement.
Then, as the best means to keep Peace, (thus Purchas'd
By me) I may with confidence presume,
The Wisedome of the Nation for their King
Will chuse their General; who shall lay down,
At Caesarina's feet, his British Crown.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Filamor, you have had a pleasing Dream,
And I was loath to wake you, till I found
My self concern'd; Britain you may subdue,
If you fight well: but for your fancy'd Conquest
Of Caesarina, let me undeceive you:
'Tis true, I have declar'd for Sovereignty,
The Title of a Queen I dote upon;
But if you offer'd me a Crown, I should
Refuse it as Gold poison'd by the giver.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Fly Brianella, and relieve my daughter,
She comes off bravely; tell her, I and Adolph
Stay for her; bid one call my Generall.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Will you not love? then I'l revenge you hatred.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: On my self, I feel my Spirits,
Like those the Chymist is extracting, search
Their brittle prison, with a hope to find
Some Vent, and then to fly into the Wind.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: In that point you may use your own discretion.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Madam, your Mother's in the Sicamor-Walk.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: I shall attend her. Exit Caesarina.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I'l stay, and get newes aside.
Out of my Servant. He whispers Filamor.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Tetrick waits you, Sir,
With modells for a Mask, he has already
Made your Witch-maker's Prophesie; I'l play
A Witch, Tetrick will be a Conjurer,
Bassus the Bard, and we'l shew your weak Father
What a pernitious Wife he doates upon: Exit Filamor.
What ailes he now, that he has lost his tongue?
Has not the Princess vex'd him?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: And will not you vex me so?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No indeed,
For, you love me, you say:

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What will not men swear; but swear your heart out,
You never shall swear me out of my Reason.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Reason! I warrant, Tetrick reads to you
The Mathematicks, you think nothing certain
But Demonstration.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Is Proof Demonstration?
Nothing but Proof is certain.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Kisse me then,
And we will prove, that One and Two make Three.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I will not two and three, pray leave your fooling,

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: In serious earnest, I would marry you.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Meaning Brianella;
Without a Portion you'r a Fortune, Madam,

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Thou art a flatt'ring Knave, I doubt

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Resolve
Your self, please to lay your Commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I've no Commands for you, but I've some Questions.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You'l hold your peace:
How many Duells did you fight at Rome?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Answer me like a Gentleman,
Was't for your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How do you look when you lie?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Not You alone,
But joyn'd with all our noble British Beauties,
Whose Honour a base Roman had traduc'd.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Your Cause slew him by my hand.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Modestly spoke; Had you no hurt?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: He prickt
An Artery, which pos'd th' Italian Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Since, you your self have study'd Surgery?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Would all Gentlemen spent their time no worse;
I have found out some Secrets.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You've a Powder,
VVhat do you call't?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No, it may prove Love-Pouder, then twill cause
The Heart-ake: in spight of my own and Love's teeth
I'l keep my heart whole. Now to my last Quaere,
What design has your Charge upon the Princess,
I see in thy sweet looks, there is some plotting.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Plotting of Knavery!
But I shall know't, my Lady will tell me,
And she'l know't if there be a Witch in Britain.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: What is thy Lady going to the Devill?
But let her go, for there's other way
To sound the bottom of Prince Filamor,
He's forty fathom deep below my plummit,
She goes to a wisewoman?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No, she means
To go to a Wiseman, to the VVitch-maker,
The Bard; who came last night into a Cave
In our VVoods, you shall bring me to the Bard,

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Fie! the Bard sings only to Princes Ears,
His Prentices, VVitches, and Conjurers
Answer Great Ladies; I'l commend you to
Th'old Witch that deals in Palmistry; but then
I'l be your husband.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: VVho shall be my husband
The VVitch must tell me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: And that Witch I'l be. Exit Fromund.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I live again, my Children are become
Their Mother's Parents: when thou, my dear Adolph,
Look'dst with the eyes of pious rage and scorn
Upon the Sacriledg of Filamor,
Who (without leave from me) durst court thy Sister,
Then my Soul clos'd in your dead Father's Urne,
Sprung from his ashes; but when Caesarina
Stood the temptation of a Showre of Gold,
Such as the Poets dream'd not of, a Crown
Offer'd her by a Prince, wise, young and handsome;
But yet my Enemy, then I felt the joys
Of Immortality, to see my self
Mother to a Beauty, born to revenge me
Upon a Villain.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Filamor's Fool. Before he went to Rome,
Filamor had the art of coz'ning Fame:
For with a Rebels Impudence he mask't
Foul Treasons under fair and specious Names:
The disimpowering me to rule my Husband
(An affront not to be forgiv'n) he call'd
Friendship to Adolph, Love to Caesarina:
He's now return'd improv'd in Villany,
Therefore tis time he went a longer Voyage.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: And whether will you send him now?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: To Hell:
Nor shall he go so far alone; his Father,

sp.speaker: Sylvanus.
sp.l: And his Sister Violinda
Shall bear him Company; th' indignity,
He would have put on me, shall ruine him
And his whole Family; I did not think
(When this Match with Sylvanus was first treated)
Occasion durst be giv'n, but I resolv'd
It should be taken; for I that was born
A Prince, and no mean Beauty, certainly
Would never have bury'd my self alive
In the cold Grave of an Old Prince's Bed,
But to rise up with his Crown on my head.
The principality of Verulam,
Which I am marry'd to, I'l joyn to that
Of Malden, which is my Inheritance,

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Give me Pow'r,
Let honest men, that go to Law, have Justice:
Subjects may plead their Titles, Princes must
Dispute what's Advantageous, not what's Just:
A Crown he merits, who piles Tow'r on Tow'r
To scale the Stars, and riffle Soveraign Pow'r:
But he that puts himself into a fright
With empty sounds, meer Terms of Wrong and Rights.
Is sitter (when his Conscience checks at them)
To wear a Mitre then a Diadem.

div.stage: Enter Crispus, Capito, Gracchus and Sergius.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My Lord,
Are not our Orders sent away to Malden,
That I see your Lieutennant-General here?

sp.speaker: Crispus.
sp.l: Yesterday your Express came to his hand
In Malden.

sp.speaker: Capito.
sp.l: Presently I hors'd the Foot,
We march'd all night, and by the break of day
I brought your Army into Barnet-Woods,
Which is within a League of Verulam,
Where safe and undiscover'd they are lodg'd
Till my Lord General Crispus please to come.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Capito, you've been active in my Service.
Our thanks is but th' earnest of your reward,
Ha! who are these?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: No, Madam, Roman Gladiators, Sword-men,
We call them Masters of Defence,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Men that fear nothing, death's their play-fellow,
They dye upon the Stage to please Spectators,

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: But were these kind of men ever imploy'd
In a great Action?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: In the Servile War;
They brought it to a measuring cast at Rome,
Which should Command in Chief the Lords or Slaves.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: I'l have ' 'em for my own Guard, tell ' 'em so;

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Gentlemen, tis the pleasure of my Prince,
On the account of Valour and of Service,
To intrust you with the Guard of her Person.

sp.speaker: Sergius.
sp.l: Tis a high honour; Gracchus, I had rather
Be trusted with her Daughter,

sp.speaker: Gracchus.
sp.l: So had I:
Pox, that a Swan's Nest, this poor Iland should
Have more great Beauties then the sever'd World.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: That narrow Seas should breed such Venuses,

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: That Brittish Whales should play with such sweet Mermaids.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: We make short Meales, you may dine ere you go.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Tis past Twelve, if by One we be a Horse-back,
We shall return by Three to do your Work.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Then you'l have time to hear what good success
The Brittish Bard will promise, do you look
Your General's Commission be drawn up
For the Conquest of Verulam; come my Lord.
sp.stage: Exeunt Pon. Cri. Cap. Bri. Grac. and Se●.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: My Mother us'd to give us better Precepts,

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: She was good-natur'd, and had sense of Honour,

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: And of Religion; but now she leaves
The Temples of the Gods, to consult Witches,
As Brianella tells me; I suppose
The General must go with her, she knows we
Are for no such black Voyages, tis strange
The General should, for he's a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Was not our Mother once as strict as he
In point of Honour, but she's chang'd; this comes
Of Malice; Sister, take you heed of Malice,
Outside and inside you'r my Mother's Picture,
In hate to Filamor you resemble her.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: I have th' ayr of her Face, not of her Vices;
I love not Filamor, as you do, Brother,
But would not be his murdress, like my Mother.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You would not with a Dart or Poniard kill
Prince Filamor, but with a Frown you will:
It were an Honour by your Hand to dye,
My Friend falls sadly, murder'd by your Eye.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: Can he be murder'd, who has pow'r to live?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: He has no pow'r, but what you please to give:
Lov'd Sister, save my dear Friend's life, and make
The noblest person happy, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Can you (who to a Brother's love pretend)
Ruine your Sister to preserve your Friend?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Free Love forc'd, destroys
More then our Fortunes, or our Lives, our Joyes;
I'l here no more on't.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: So, you'l part in anger,
And take this fair occasion to break promise?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Did not you promise me, to beg
Princesse Violindas's Picture?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: For my self?
But you shall have it.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: But if I get y' her Picture, you must do
Something for me.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Something, nay any thing;
Still my best Sister.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: But when I enjoyn you
To take off him, for whom you thus torment me, aside
I shall be your worst Sister; for this Picture,
You will do whatsoever I Command?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Give me her Picture, and command my Life.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: A Lover's life? what's that? some Authors say,
You've one to keep, and eight to give away:
Muster your nine Lives, Brother, if you'l stand
My Charge, for 'tis your Patience I'l Command.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Sylvanus, Filamor, and Violinda in the Woods.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: BLessing on Blessing fall upon my Son,
Faster then tears fall from my Eyes for Joy
To see thee in my Arms, I'l keep thee here,
Thou shalt travail no more.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Yes, if I say,
That 'tis not fit your wife should govern you.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Alas! I could not eat nor sleep in quiet,
Till I had told her, that 'twas thy advice:
Excuse the weakness of thy Father's age,
I was not born a Cowr'd.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Your Valour, Sir
Is one of Brinains memorable Fortunes;
For when Arcadius and Honorius lost
Their Laurell to the Scots, then you defeated
A Cohort of the Roman Horse of Malden.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: A man would think those Romans ran away
VVith my commanding Pow'r, for, ever since
I marry'd Pontia, I've serv'd under her,
She shall obey me now.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Spoke like a Prince
That understands the duty of his Subjects.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'l have no Governess— but if my wife
Knew of our Meeting—

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: She'l take 't unkindly, and I would not grieve her,
Because she Loves me; she'l not stay thus long
From me— by this she's in my Bed-Chamber,
And misses me.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: No, Sir, no Creature comes
Into your Bed-Chamber, the doors are bolted,
And your Physitians (fee'd by me) give out,
You rested not last Night, and have took something
To procure sleep.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Then Filamor makes this
A day of happiness to his old Father.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Sir, you'l make this day happy to your Children,
If you'l lay your Commands on Violinda
To Love her Servant, my brave Friend, Prince Adolph;
I am a Suitor for him.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: So am I,
And two such Suitors must have no denial.

sp.speaker: Violinda.
sp.l: My Brother knows, Sir, that I love Prince Adolph,
As much as he loves Filamor:

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Enough,
'Tis enough in all conscience, Violinda.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: In conscience: Violinda should love him
As much as he loves her, he doats upon her.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Then I would have thee doat upon him too.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Adolph's my Brother's Friend, and Caesarina
Is my Friend; Sir, for both I have a friendship:
But that I should love Caesarina's Brother
Unless she's loves my Brother, there's no reason.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: No reason, Girl, I am for thee again.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Away, you triffler, you spin out the time,
Knowing I must prepare for th' entertainment
Of my Step-Mother.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: My wife shall not come to me,
I'l go to her.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: She shall not see you here,
Pray, stay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Cross me not; I vow I'l go.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I must call Tetrick to him: Come away
My Father's leaving us.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: You never think
Of me, but when you'r at a loss; I'l meddle
With no blown business.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Keep him in the Woods,
And I will make thee Lord of the whole Forest,

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Excuse, Original Infirmity,
My humour's peevish, Sir, but my hearts good;
I'l stop your Father's hast: Sir, I must Charm you.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: A Conjurer? I will so devill thee, he beats Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: Hold, hold your hand Sir; I'm your Servant Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: I am justly punish'd
For looking ugly.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Follow me, thou know'st
My sweet wife loves me.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: That's the Question, Sir
Be pleas'd to stay and you will hear 't determin'd;
Matter of Fact 's this, The Princess of Malden,
Your wife, intended to have dealt with Witches
For the bewitching you (some say) to death:
Your Son diverts her with the artifice
Of setting up (as she thinks) a Witch-maker,
Call'd (for the singing of's Predictions)
The British Bard; as soon as she has din'd
Your wife comes to the Bard's Cave, then you'l know
Whether she loves or hates you.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Son, I'l stay;
But hide me from my wife.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: She shall not see you. Exit Syl. and Fil.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Fromund, I Conjure thee, appear O Witch.
All goes as well as heart can wish, th' old Prince
Is now ingag'd.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Yonder comes Brianella,
My Mistress, with a Basket full of Plate,
Her Lady's offering to the British Bard:
You owe me thanks for 't, I hinted the Plate,
We must help one another,

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: In requital Enter Brianella, and her Maid with a Basket.
I'l make teee tell her Fortune; speak out Sister,
You do so mumble, what would y' have me do?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Move the great Witch-maker, the British Bard,
To inlarge my Commission with power
Of Life and Death, over Plants, Beasts, and Men.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Sooner or latter, I am sure,
I must come to the Faggot and the Fire;
Shall I be burn'd for nothing?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: One year more
You must tell Fortunes by the Hand; next Spring▪
I'l move the Bard for you, pretty sweet Sister.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: In the mean time, if I might but bewitch
Dumb Creatures, only Monkeys, Cats, and Dogs:
A scurvy proud young Widow, yesternight,
Call'd me old Beldam, let me but bewitch
Her little Dog; though she bears patiently
The loss of a kind Husband, yet the death of
Her little Dog (I'm sure) will break her heart.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Teach me? I'l pull thy nose off, and that Dog
Shall eat it: go, take from that noble Lady
That Basket full of Plate, look in her hand
And tell her Fortune.

div.stage: Enter Pontia, Crispus, Gracchus and Sergius.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: But Mother, Mother, I hope we shall meet,

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: At the Mark-Beech, an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I'l not fail.
O Madam! they know all things; the Magician
Could tell me, 'twas a Basket full of Plate.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Ministers of Fate, I come to know the Issue
Of a design of Blood.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: My Song will fit her aside.
Madam, we'r not impowr'd to answer Princes,
That's reserv'd for the Bard himself, who now
sp.stage: In the Bard's Cave is discovered a man with a grey beard, in a Russet Gown, sleeping with a Harp in his hand.
sp.l: Lyes in a Trance: I'l hold up to his Soul
Your Princely Off'ring, with the names of those
You vow to death, if you'l but write them down,
'Tis the Bard's Custome.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: Bring Pen, Ink and Paper. She writes, and gives the Paper to Tetrick.

div.stage: DIS MANIBUS. Pontia devotes to hell Filamor, Violinda and Sylvanus.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: So, I've her Treason, now, under her hand.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: With our usual Ceremony
Of Musique and a Dance.

div.stage: Tet. and From. hold up to the Bard the List and the Basket, to which Sergius points.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Look you there Sirrha,

l.foreign: Barbara de pictis veni Bascauda Britannis:

sp.l: That British Bascaud would sell well at Rome.

sp.speaker: Gracc.
sp.l: So would the pretty Maid that brought the Vascaud;
But Princess Caesarina for my money.

div.stage: Tetrick and Fromund fall into a Dance, then comes in another Conjurer, and another Witch, and from under his Coat and her Gown, drop out two little Familiars, an he and a she. At the end of this Antique, the Bard wakes, and sings.

lg.head: The Bard's Song.
lg.l: And the crafty young Fox withdrawes,
Then the Scene of Blood is acted;
Then the Wood- Nymphs run distracted;
Brasse Basons and Trumpets are sounding;
Out of the Eclipse she was drown'd in.
Not a Clowd in the Skie:

div.stage: The Scene of the Bard is shut up, Manent Pontia, Crispus, Brianella, and the Gladiators.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: You'r now impowr'd to conquer Verulam; Pontia gives the Commission to Crispus.
What do you think of the success presag'd?
My Lord, what's your opinion of the Bard?

sp.speaker: Crispus,
sp.p: First, Madam, give me leave to hear your judgment.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I take him to be somewhat more then humane;
He speaks the Language of another World,
So well; that his expressions are all Picture;
The fair Fawn, the young Fox, and the white Raven
Is clearly my old Husband and his Children;
The Moon eclyps'd that's I, whose light is drown'd
Till your victorious Drums and Trumpets sound:
You have my sense, give me your own; I know
Crispus to be a man of so much worth,
He scorns to flatter any Prince; speak freely.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: E're we end our discourse, I'le clear that point:
She'l find I am no flatterer, I have watcht
A long time for this opportunity, aside.
To set a Looking-glass before her Soul:
Then freely (since I have it in command)
I think our Druids Prophets; but our Bards
(Like all the tribe of Fortune-tellers) Juglers.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Then you believe not this to be a Vision;
What do you think it is?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Intelligence
From his confederate Knaves; you are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: And so, you would advise, not to proceed?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Madam, had I been of your Cabinet-Counsel,
You should not have begun it. What's, your quarell?
Th'Opinion, That Wives should not rule their Husbands,
For these words spoken by a Child (for then
Prince Filamor was not sixteen years old,
You'l ruine him, his Sister, and your Husband;
Strange grounds for murdring Princes, and for Vesting
All their Dominions in your self.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Yet, Sir,
Some Counsellors that are as wise as You,
Have approv'd both the Grounds and the Design.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: If by wise, your Highness means Politique,
I grant those Counsellors were more wise than I:
For, my simplicity will never flatter
My Prince into a Deity; I cannot
Tell you, that Princes are exempted from
The Law of Nations; that Revenge and Murder
(Stains in the Meane) are Triumphs to the Great:
I cannot find out Presidents for Injustice,
Nor instance (as your Flatterers have done)
That if particular Rights had been preserv'd,
The World had been unconquer'd, Macedon
One private Kingdom still, and Rome another.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: What are the Maxims upon which you build?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: My Principles are Honesty and Honour,
Jewels of value in a poor man's hand,
Inestinmable in a Prince's Breast:
How happy our Posterity will live
Under a Prince character'd by a Druid
Who prophecies that you little British Princes
Shall kneel to one King, and describes him.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: How?
May we hear the description?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I remember
So much as shews the great disparity
Between You and that Monarch: Thus 't begins,
Now in Britain reigns a King,
Young and active as the Spring;
And pray observe it, Madam, thus it ends,
He has Valour, such as might
For the whole World safely fight:
Wisdome, which could rule it too;
But he's Just, and will not do
For a thousand Worlds one Wrong:
Never did his spirit long,
On another Prince's Throne
(By meer Pow'r) to raise his own.
And so far, for any ends,
Is he from destroying Friends,
Th at ev'n his Enemies confesse
His Mercy to the Mercilesse.
Make this Just King your Pattern.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Sawcy fool; She strikes the Commission out of his hand.
Deliver your Commission; we shall chuse
A Generall, not a Tutor.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Humbly thus, He layes down his Commission at her feet.
My publique Person I put off, and pray,
That, as a private man, I may be heard.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: But not for your Commission; young man,
You have a Successor: he's in my eye;
Capito's our Generall.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: For him I move,
(In reference to your safety) that you'l put him
Into immediate Action, else you'r lost.
For (if I understand the Bard) you lie
Open to Filamor, your plot's betray'd,
Your life at stake: the Question is not now,
On what ill Grounds you have begun, but how
(Being ingag'd) you may preserve your Self.
That's a Just Cause, in which your nicest Subject
May draw his Sword with honour.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: And who worthier,
In a Just Cause, to be our Generall,
Then noble Crispus? There, take your Commission.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No, Madam; as the Romans manumit
Their Slaves, you have freed Crispus with a blow;
You struck me, as men strike their swounding friends,
To bring me to my Senses: hitherto,
Devotion to your service first, and then
My own concern (both as to Fame, and Fortune)
Gave me the trouble of distracted hopes:
Now all the lines of my Ambition
Meet in one little point (touch d by your hand,)
I centre in my Self: fix'd to enjoy
The pleasure of a private life; retirement
From splendor, and from Care, which presses in
To gilded Rooms; Porters at Prince's Gates
Could never keep out Care and Fear, two strangers
To low-rooft Houses, where I'l live and dye.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Will Crispus do a Service to his Prince
With such disservice, as to let me know
My Cause is just, and make the World suspect it,
By quitting the Imployment?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Pardon me;
Should the Gods send their winged Messenger
With that Commission, and all their Hands to it,
The Gods should pardon me. He offers to go.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Stay, if he goes,
In my Attempt I can proceed no further;
We may use valiant Rogues to do a Murder; aside.
But Polititians are concern'd to find
Persons of Worth, when Conquests are design'd.
Crispus, how high a value I have for thee,
Let my great Heart demonstrate, which descends
Below it self, to an acknowledgment
That I have wrong'd theee.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: When I serve again,
I'l take up your Commission.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: So obstinate?
Then I stand up my self, your Prince, Accept it
From my Command.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: You may command my Head,
My Hand shall be my Subject.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Yet hear Reason,
Though you'l not hear your Prince; you censure me
For secking to destroy a Family
For a Boy's words; yet for a Woman's words
(And she your Sovegraign) you can dispense
With Loyalty in your self, abandoning
Your Prince to her awaken'd Enimies.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Justly I am rebuk'd; upon my knee He takes up the Commission.
I beg your pardon, and accept your favour;
Longer to hold you in discourse, were dangerous
To your Affairs; I take my humble leave:
Now that your Sword is in my Hand again,
It shall not freeze, I'l strike a suddain blow;
Fortune's swift-turning Wheel deceives the slow.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Capito, you perceive, that in our Army
You hold the second Place, to have the first;
At the next Vacancy

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: Let me serve your Highness
In any Place, 'tis to my hand alike,
To bear a Truncheon or to trail a Pike. Exit Capito.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Other men are Flesh and Blood, the General, Fire;
Here were a Husband now, if one could catch him:
Old Witch, I'l venture at thy Lottery
All my Gold, but I'l draw a General.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: The suddain blow tis I must strike, not Crispus;
Before he comes, Filamor may be fled:
Filamor's the Bard's Fox, Crispus my Lion,
Valiant, but generous, I know he'l seize,
But that's all, for he'l never kill the Prey,
Nor can I, bare-fac'd, do't; that Foxe's case
Shall piece this Lion's skin— Go Brianella,
Bid Caesarina meet me at the Poplars,
I've new Instructions for her, she must smooth
Her fore-head when she looks upon the Prince;
Do you seek him out, and tell Filamor
You'r not sent by my Daughter, (nor forbid)
To let him know (after his Mask) if he
Take her out, she'l dance with him.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: The Gods are bound in Honour to perform
What they have promis'd by the British Bard.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Filamor's life's upon't;
And my Hand shall revenge his base affront,

div.stage: Enter Caesarina and Violinda with Picture-Tablets in their hands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: If with our Pictures we could change our selves,
I would be you: Would you be Violinda?

sp.speaker: Caesarina.
sp.l: And never wish to be my self again;
If I were Violinda, I'd not Change
With Caesarina for the World to boot
But Violinda were you Caesarina,
You would not love your Brother Filamor.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What would he care for my hate, when you lov'd him?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: My love would hardly please him were we chang'd,
For I should be his Sister, you his Mistress,
And you would be no kinder then I am,
But here's my Brother. Enter Adolph.

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: Madam, you fly from me; as if our Hearts
Mov'd upon Needles touch'd by th' opposite Poles,
Of the Celestial Loadstone Love, yet may
I mention it to you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: From that I fly,
And not from you; I've an Esteem for you,
As Brother to my Friend; but till she love
My Brother, when you mention love to me;
I shall retire. Exit Violinda.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You see, how I'm concern'd
To be my Friend's Sollicitor in his Suit.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: Sollicit me for your Mistresse's Picture.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Have you her Picture, that's some comfort yet,
This Violinda and I will never part.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: Hold, you'r not like to meet, but on Conditions.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Have I not Sign'd a Blank? fill you it up
With your own Articles.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: First, you shall promise,
Never more to move me for Filamor.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: You are not (sure you cannot be) in earnest?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I am silenc'd,
Let Filamor's own Merits speak for him—
Come—

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Have you
A pair of these Commands?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: You shall ingage,
To use your best endeavours to perswade
Filamor to relinquish his pretence
Of Love to me.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And all this for a Picture?
Would y' have me loose, like Aesop's Dog, the substance
With catching at the Shadow? You know, Sister,
On Filamor's hope of you, depends my hope
Of Violinda.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Let what will depend;
These are your Termes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You think, I'l not accept them?
Give me the Picture, I'l undo my self
To be reveng'd on thee; such pow'rfull Reasons
I'l give my Friend against thee— he shall take up
Thy scorn, and thou (as he does now) shalt sigh
(When Filamor enjoyes a greater Beauty)
And say, That matchless Prince was once my Servant.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Well, I have all, I would have; here's the Picture,
And there's your Man, look you to your Ingagement.

sp.speaker: Filamor,
sp.l: Dance with me? Caesarina dance with me?
One name may sound, at distance, like another,
Did she name me? Madam, excuse my doubts,
I do believe you, yet so great an honour,
To me so unexpected, on the suddain
Puzzled my faith: I owe to Brianeila
For the first newes that makes me Fortunate.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: But, Sir, you must conceal th Intelligence,
Or else you'l lose your Spie.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I'd rather lose
Verulam.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You'r not like to keep it long, aside.
But to tell that, is out of my Commission:
I take my humble leave.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Maid.
Compar'd to me, how happy art thou Adolph,
When Violinda gives thee a denial,
She grieves thee with so much Civility.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Your sister carries it the handsomer;
Mine, like a Tigresse, shews an angry fore-head,
Her fury lightens in her eyes: your Sister
Poisons me, like a Polititian, smiling;
Long since I'd burst, but for this Antidote
Our Friendship, Filamor. Embraces.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Our Friendship, Adolph,
Is a felicity which ballances
All our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Love it self gives place
To Friendship in my Herauldry.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Take heed
How you set up Friendship against Love, Adolph,
Love is a God.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: He is, and we are Men,
Who importune the Gods, and give them trouble
With Pray'rs and Sacrifices for our Loves;
But what Wives they will prove, Heav'n only knows:
We may pray for a curse, and some kind God
May crosse us for a blessing— let me tell you
(As I do love you) truly, I suspect
My Sister.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: That was a Princely check upon his tongue.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I know, my Sister will be no good Wife.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: If any man, but Adolph, told me so,
I should not be thus patient.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: In plain terms,
I know, my Sister will be an ill Wife.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Is't madnesse? or is't envy that asperses
Thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Wherefore do you furle your brow?
I tell you Caesarina is not worth
A thought of Filamor's.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Unsay thy words,
Whilst we are friends.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: If you remember her,
Let it be so as we remember Tyrants,
For th'evill they have done.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Be wise betimes,
Kneel, and beg pardon of thy Sister's virtue:
Yet we are friends.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Therefore I am oblig'd
To disabuse you—

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Friendship, up to heaven,
From whence thou cam'st; against this Enemy,
The Common Enemy of Love and Virtue,
I draw the Sword of Justice. Fil. drawes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Hear me out, Ad. drawes.
Before I set this Seal upon thy hearing;
What Fury strikes out that clear light, thy Reason?
Are you so blind, so obstinately blind,
You will not see a dreadful Precipice,
When I point to it? If you'l not believe
Your Friend, you have before your eyes the sad
Example of your Father, good old man!
How like a child is he aw'd by my Mother!
There's twenty thousand Mothers in my Sister;
Already she begins her tyrannous reign,
And makes you more a child than your weak Father,
Or else you would have more Sence then to love
One that scorns you. I've done.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: And I begin;
First, let me joy my self, for cancelling
The long misplac'd relation of a Friend
To so unnatural a Brother; then,
Thou stranger to my heart, in thy heart's blood
I'l wash off the durt cast upon thy Sister.
Not love her? Why? because she scorns me? fool,
I would not love her if she did not scorn
One of no merit.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Then you do her wrong,
To move my Sister for one of no merit.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Unworthy man, that which thou would'st destroy,
My Love to her, creates in me a Merit.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Alas poor Filamor, to deceive thy self
What curious Art thou hast, what subtile non-cense,
A merit and no Merit? and for this,
The fast and loose, the Juggle of a Word,
Thou draw'st upon thy friend?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Dear friend, forgive me,
Something you said (which concern'd Caesarina)
That put me into passion; what it was
I have forgot, but as 'tis stated now,
I must confesse, I blush to find my self
In this offensive posture.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Put not up
Your sword; for you may fight, and you may chuse:
Will you relinquish all pretence of love
To Caesarina?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Not whilst I've a sword,
And strength to guide to thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: 'Tis well;
I'm glad to hear that you are so resolved:
You may fight; but, Filamor, if you do,
You shall fight with my Sister. For this Picture,
(A part of Filamor, and Adolph's All)
I promis'd Caesarina, to perswade you
(With my best oratory) to relinquish
Your love to her; I have perform'd: and you,
Before, like a rough Diamond, only rich
In my belief thus polish'd, strikes my eyes:
Amaz'd to meet so glorious a surprize.
Filamor's estimate is trebbled now
In Adolph's valuation; and by this time
(You have yet more advantage by your triall,
For) Caesarina's heart (I warrant) akes
For fear I should prevail.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: She meant (I hope
I flatter not my self) to try, if she
Might venture on me any further Grace
Then th'honour she intends me at my Mask,
To dance with me.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: That's some kindness yet; my Sister
Has but one fault, she thinks Love is below her;
But Friend if, from so high a pitch, her Pride
Can stoop to any Husband, she's thy Bride. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Brianella at one Door; at another, Fromund like a Witch.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: THis is th' appointed place; there's the Mark-Beech,
And the old Witch too; luck an't be thy will:
A General, I beseech thee, gracious Beldam;
Mother, you are a Woman of your word.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: O my good Daughter, neither Man nor Woman
Will break their word with you; show me your hand,
Off with your Glove: Ay marry, Child, if Caesar
Were now our Lord, he would send for his Guards
That watch th' Arabian Trees, and set them Centree
Upon this Balm.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: A Complemental Hag, aside.
How come you to be such a Courtier, Mother?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: I shall be catch'd— First, Daughter, I pray resolve me,
Did never any Gentleman, at Court,
Tell you your Fortune?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Then if your Hand
Can turn a Courtier to a Fortune-Teller;
Why may't not make us Fortune-Tellers Courtiers?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: A pleasant Witch: what? Compasses? do you
Mean to survey my Hand with your Glass-eyes?
Come, on with them: First, how long shall I live?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Here's a deep Life-line, without Cross or Break;
Ten, twenty, thirty, you'l live, till you be
Just a year older then am I, a hundred. Fromund with his compasses measures her Vital Line.

sp.speaker: Bri,
sp.p: That's long enough; shall I be fortunate?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: I never saw such a prosperity-line
Running quite through your Triangle; it cuts
Your Table-line, and has the noblest Sister,
You'l be Right Honourable.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: So, here's Fortune,
And Honour; but what Pleasure? how many Husbands?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: To that what sayes the Mount of Mercury?
Tis cross'd with one Line, you'l have but one Husband,

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: How? but one Husband in a hundred years?
O pittiful!

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: But in the Mount of Venus
Are Stars; in Sol and Iupiter a Zone;
A Venus-Girle, you'l have store of Servants.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: At foot of Iove's Mount,
Your Capital line and your Vital line
Meet in an acute Angle, which demonstrates,
Your Head holds correspondence with your Heart:
You'l not tell any Secrets of your own.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No, if I do; like a poor Vestal-Nun
That can't keep Counsel when she meets her Servant,
Let me be bury'd alive; this one Husband
Will be (I hope) a good one: pray, what manner
Of Man?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Black hair, not curl'd by Art, but Nature;
Good hopefull Signs.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: To day,
He courted you for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Ha! that's Fromund?
He has a voluble Tongue?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: The Gudgeon bites. aside.
A winning way (she's taken with my Courtship) aside.
The young man Complements better then th' old Witch.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: One who in Forreign parts
Has noted Men and Manners; I'm cock-sure. aside.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: In some Place, or Imployment,
About a Prince: she's mine, from all the World. aside.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Prince Filamor's Tutor, Fromund, out upon him
A younger Brother. Fromund is about to discover himself.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: So, so, my Cake's dow,
When I believ'd my self to be cock-sure,
If I had flung off my disguise, how she
Had laught at me?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Daughter, I am considering your Condition,
Will you lead Apes in Hell.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Yes, (Apes is something
To trust to) rather then I'l marry Hopes:
I am for Honour, and Estate in Hand,
No promising Husband is for me; can you
Change me this Courtier for a General?
For Fromund I'l not give one farthing-token.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: He's much bound to you. aside.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Make it my Lord Crispus,
You shall have the worth of a hundred pieces,
This Saphyr-Ring.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: If you would give me London,
I cannot find a General in your Hand.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: But the young Conjurer makes Love to me,
And I'l lay my Commands upon my Servant,
To search the Stars for my Lord General.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Take the Ring; Mother: when shall I hear of you?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: In th'Evening: mean time, if you could but get
Your Lady to move my Lord Crispus for you.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: That I am sure she will. Fromund throwes off the Witches habit.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Then I am sure— Exit Brianella.
The Generall will not have thee, he's a person
Of so much honour, that he'l never marry
One, thy dishonourable Lady speaks for:
There's life in't yet; Tetrick, I must have thee
To help me in the businesse of my love.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: The devill's in't, when men make love their business;
Thou a man? thou a horse: and would thou hadst
(Besides thy amorous curvetting qualme)
All the diseases of a horse: I help thee?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Thee I have help'd, and may prove to thy parse
More instrumentall yet.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Why, look you, Fromund,
How you misconstrue me: I'l serve your love,
If you will love at seasonable times,
But to stand fooling now, when Pontia,
Th'Illustrious Traytresse, takes up Gladiators
To murder our great Master— here he Enter Sylvanu reading a Paper. comes
Reading the bloody List she gave the Bard.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Dis Manibus. Pontia devotes to hell
Filamor, Violinda, and Sylvanus—
Am I here? Is my name down? thank you, Wife;
Kind second wife, I very humbly thank you
For the recovery of my Wits— you hear
No news?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: But what you hear from me—

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: What news is that, Sir? Syl. frowns on Fromund.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: That we have heard oft. Syl. smiles on Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: But when, Tetrick? when?
Before I marry'd Pontia; never since,
Till now.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: And now you understand your danger?
Prevent it in her ruine.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You'r a fool;
Shall I destroy my wife for her first fault?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: That were to imitate her cruelty.

sp.speaker: Fro .
sp.l: But you'l forget your Promise,
Be pleas'd to write it down.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'l set my hand
To nothing—

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: That's unprincely: but 'tis just
To write as she did, your Note for her Note.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: 'Tis just indeed, I'l underwrite her Paper.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: You'l find her Pen and Ink too ith'Bard's Cave.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: See how Affection swayes! though both our Reasons
Were of one colour, mine look'd dull; thine bright,
When Prejudice and Favour chang'd the light.

div.stage: Enter Pontia, Caesarina, Violinda, Brianella, Gracchus and Sergius.

sp.speaker: Pontia,
sp.l: This Mask was made for you by Filamor,
And therefore if he take you out to dance,
Dance with him Caesarina, though you love not
The Man, be civill to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: After the Masque, whither will you two walk?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Just into the Lion's pawes; aside.
O excellent, incomparable Bard!
Gracchus and Sergius, you know the Lawne?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Then hang well,
If either he or I neglect your service.

sp.speaker: Gracc.
sp.l: Our Roman Swords shall fall upon your Foes,
Swifter then Arrowes from your British bowes.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: When the Masque's done, remember Brianella,
Your part.

sp.speaker: Brianella.
sp.l: Your Message to the Prince shall be
Deliver'd, as from Princess Caesarina.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Filamor will believe thee, when he sees
Thy first newes (of her dancing with him) true:
Do't carefully, and I'l make thee my care,
The Generall will not deny thy love
VVhen I move for thee.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: My Dear; what are these Maskers? They sit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Ovid's Huntsmen:
Their Forms (chang'd by his Gods) the God of Hunting,
Apollo, has restor'd to Phaeton,
Cephalus and Actaeon.

div.stage: The Scene, a Grove, in which is a Lawrell Tree, and three Poplar Trees.

sp.speaker: Phaë.
sp.l: Hey! brother— Wood-men come away,
Actaeon? Cephalus? So ho? Enter Fil. & Adolph as Cephalus and Actaeon.
Chorus within.
Never may they see Sport, who stay
When Phaeton sayes, Come, or Go:

p.hi: Shall we rouze the long-liv'd Hart?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Ask the Youthfull God of Art,
(Who restor'd us our Forms) Apollo,
My Father promis'd he would follow: Enter Apollo.
See, the great Huntsman comes at last.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: Our morning-Rites in Delphos past;
I came to London, where my Sister
Dwells in her Temple; but I miss'd her:
For (vex'd with things, which fools desir'd)
She was into her Grove retir'd:
Then swift as ever Lightning flew,
I cut the Clowds, and sail'd to You.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: Yes,
Four of the Metamorphosis:
In those three Poplars grow thy Sisters,
That Laurell Cloisters my coy Mistris;
We two will untransform them now.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: My sacred Tree,
That Conquerors and Poets browes
Crown'st with thy immortall boughs,
From thunder free,
With Musique shaken, cleave asunder, The Laurell opens, and in it appears Daphne.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Ay me! a suddain clap of thunder
Could not strike Daphne's heart so dead,
As does that Voice, from which I fled
To this Tree, that (whea th'Earth deny'd me)
Open'd, and shut again to hide me:
False Laurell, wer't thou kind so long,
At last to sell me for a Song?
What hope that Strangers will be just,
When our old Friends betray their trust?
Cruell Apollo, dost thou give
Life to a Maid who fears to live?
Some gentler God take Daphne's part,
And close my Tree, or break my Heart.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: Sweet Nymph, thy Panick Fear dismiss,
Apollo will not force a kiss.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.p: Why then for Daphne do you call?

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: This is the Huntsman's Festivall,
We'l only dance together.

sp.speaker: Daph.
sp.l: Then Daphne may
(With honour) say,
Apollo's welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Dear Sisters, that (when I was drown'd)
Wept your selves into Poplar-Trees:
Now my Platonick Year's come round,
Enjoy the Light which Phaeton sees;
Phaethusa?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Not Filamor, but Cephalus begs the honour
Of a Corant.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.p: Come my bold Sword-men, now you'l have imployment,

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: May I presume to kiss the Princely hand
To which I owe this honour.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Does my bounty
Incourage begging? you shall be content
VVith the next favour you receive from me.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: So does the covetous Fav'rite lose his place,
By offering to impose upon free Grace.

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: My Sister's too high-hearted to be govern'd;
Proud Minds, like billowes in a storm, are toss'd
At their own rate; but if you steer, y'are lost.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: What a dull fool was I to lose her thus?
I hope not; here comes one who can resolve me;
Dear friend, leave me alone with my Good Angel.

sp.speaker: Adol.
sp.l: VVhat means he? is the Devil his Good Angel?
My Mother's Messenger? I'l hear Adolph stands and listens. her newes.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: Now Brianella, speak; is't life, or death?

sp.speaker: Brianella.
sp.l: Life, life Sir, Princess Caesarina walks
To gather Violets in the Lawne, from thence
She strikes up to the Lime-tree Grove, come thither,
But keep your masking habit on, she said,
If so by chance you met her in that Grove,
You might have better Audience as a Huntsman,
Then ever yet she gave you as a Prince.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: How's that? my Mother has a Plot upon him:
This cannot be a Message from my Sister.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: This Embassage shall put about thy neck
A string of Pearl.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: A string of hemp were fitter, aside.
I am sure I deserve't, If you knew all:
Excuse me; if my Lady call, she may
Suspect my absence. Exit Brianella.

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: Filamor, no haste,
You shall not go.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Then you shall kill me, Adolph;
For if I live, I'l go.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: You are not mad?
Do you know, who invites you? Brianella,
My Mother's Confident, the Agent for
Thy cruel Step-Mother, who seeks thy blood:
Do you know, what she said? Is't probable,
My Sister (who scorn'd th'offer of a Crown)
VVill love a Masking Suit?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Was't probable,
Your Sister would have danc'd with me? yet she would;
And Brianella praeacquainted me
With her intention: non ore words, I'l go.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: A happy voyage; I'l be there before you:
She told him, Caesarina's in the Lawne;
If he go thither, 'tis upon the Bow;
I know the String, the strait path to the Grove;
And whosoever is to meet him there,
Shall find me on the place, to answer for him.

sp.speaker: Sergius.
sp.l: Our Trade is to kill men, we never yet
Shed Woman's blood.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: And my Reward: you shall be so rewarded,
You'l wish I had more Princess Violinda's
For you to kill.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: May we not have the honour
Of murdering her brother?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: That's reserv'd
For my hand; none shall revenge Pontia,
But Pontia.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: If the Prince, your husband, wants
An Officer— to cut his Throat—

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: For him,
I'l provide meaner Instruments, there's Gold,
Jewels too; You are Strangers, and the Natives
(After this fact, if they can take you) will
Tear you to pieces: To prevent your danger
You see my Groom waits for you with good horses,
Fly; though for me you have lost Italy,
And must lose Britain; wheresoe're you land,
You'l make your selves a Country with that Treasure;
Romans farewell.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Our saddest losse is, such
A bounteous Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: And it wounds us deeper
Then we can wound the Princess, when our Swords
Shall weep her blood.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: But Gentlemen, pray kill
My Daughter-in-Law with as little fright
To my own Daughter, as is possible:
If you bind Caesarina, bind her gently. Exit Pontia.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: As gently as these arms can bind a Lady;
To kill her Step-Daughter, she gives me a stock,
Will keep me like a man on any Ground;
But before I leave Britain, I'l be bold
To ravish her own Daughter; I have had
A Stomack to her long.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Meat for your Master;
Thou ravish her? I'l ravish her my self;
Room for your betters, from the Gracchi I am
Descended.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: No, degenerated, Raskal;
When we play'd Prizes on the Stage at Rome,
Then wert not thou my Mimick? did not I,
With this short Faucheon, round about the Stage,
Chase thee in that high crown'd Hat, with Gold-labells?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: And what did I, the while?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, at my Head
(Helmet and all, in which I wore this Fish)
Thou flungst a Casting-Net, and crydst, fear nothing,
I catch not you Sir, I catch but your Fish.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Upbraided with my Calling? Ganlick-Rogue,
You Country-low, did not I hear thee Beg
(Like a cow'd Slave) the People's suff'rages;
To give thee leave to take up that white wand,
The Rudies (which discharges Sword-Players,
From fear of playing Prizes by Command)
And wilt thou play a new Prize for a Princesse?
Come on.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Take notice of this Thumb reverst, Sergius draws, and bends his Thumb back.
The sign of death to Fencers.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Hold, you puppy,
What? Roman against Roman? lets draw Cuts?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Then I bend down my Thumb; live, to be hang'd:
The long cut carries her. They draw cuts.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Fortune's a Slut,
To give the prop'rer man the shorter Cut:
No remedy, I must content my self
With Princess Violinda.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: Here she comes,
Princesses by your leave, I'm somewhat bold.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: No faith, tis but a Rape.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Peace, you shrill Grashopper,
Or I'l open your Heart to stop your mouth;
Do y' see this triffle, this was Tarquin's Dagger,
And knows the way to Rape. Enter Filamor.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.l: Prodigious Villain
Look a man in the Face.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: That's not so pleasant
As looking Babyes in a Ladye's Eyes:
Help Gracchus. Serg. falls.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: There's a poor Remembrance Gracchus comes behind Filamor, and runs him in at the left arm: Filamor runs him into the Body: Gracchus falls, and mak'd a strange Grimas grinning like a dead man. for you.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Die like a Coward: he's dead out-right that stirs;
Answer, what put into your hearts a hope
To ravish Princesses?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: The Devil-Lust;
There was a Devil (of their own Sex) in 't,
The Devil Pontia— she contracted for
The Life of Violinda—

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I have paid
Your Wages, Slave. Sergius stretches out himself as dead.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: How it afflicts me, that my cruel Mother
Should be my dear Friend's mortal Enemy,
And seek the Life I prize above my own?
Your Brother bleeds much, Violinda; have you
Nothing about you that will stop his Wound?
Tear, tear my Handkercher! Pray, take it Sir,
Lose not you self in the preserving me;
You look pale.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Madam, My Wound blushes for me,
To hear your preservation ascrib'd
To Filamor, 'twas Innocence preserv'd you,
When betray'd by this habit.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: By th' honour you intended me, if thus
'T had been my Fortune to have met you in
The Lime-Tree Grove.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Has she not abus'd
Your Brother too, and sent him to meet me
Among the Lime-Trees? to that Grove he went,
Just as we turn'd into the Lawne.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Did Adolph?
Excuse me, Madam, I must needs go see
What becomes of my Friend.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Tis a Bow-shot
To the place, if you go thus bleeding thither,
You'l faint.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I'l die, before I leave Prince Adolph
To danger. Exit Filamor.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Let us follow Filamor,
I hear my Mother has a plot upon him.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: 'Twas well for me that I was bred a Mimick,
If I could not have made strange ugly Faces,
And imitated the Grimas of Death,
The very last grinn, I had never past
For a dead man; Dead-man indeed, by'r leave,
Your Gold and Jewels too fall to my Gracchus searches Sergius his Pocket. share,
By the right of Survivorship.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: The right Sergius gets upon his Feet.
Of a Fool's head: soft; Hands off, Goodman Gracchus,
Or I'l so slice your Fingers—

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: What? another
Dead man's Ape? nay, Sergius, if you out-do me
At my own Weapon, I'l give thee the Bucklers:
Hereafter we'l turn Tables (since thou art
The better Zany,) thou shalt be my Mimick.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Come, let's not fool away our Lives, and stay
Untill the Hangman cure our wounds; our Horses
Stand ready: Farewel Britain, where the Ladies
Yield not to Romans.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Where we have no luck
In any thing; for as the Mastives fly on's,
So do the Men, and they both fright like Lions. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: Sure all but I forget this Lune-tree Grove;
Here's neither Filamor, not Caesarina,
Nor any of my Mother's blood-hounds; ha!
My nose bleeds, and these drops some hold to be
Ominous Effects, when they've a natural Cause,
The fear that hants a Lover till he sees
His absent Mistress safe: but Violinda
Thou art not altogether absent from me,
For here— here sits thy Proxy, in my bosome
I wear thy painted Representative
In Gold, too poor a Temple for my Goddesse.

div.stage: Enter Pontia with a Poniard in her hand.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: The strong imagination Filamor has
That Caesarina is to meet him here,
And something in my face resembling her,
Will passe me, and my Poniard.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Fair'st of Pictures, Adolph opens his buttons.
Come forth, thou dear Companion to my heart.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Fall right; go now, and counsel thy old Father
Not to be rul'd by's Wife.

div.stage: As she stabbs Adolph, enter Filamor staggering, Caesarina, Violinda, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.l: I come too late
To save my friend, but not to perish with him.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: My Son Adolph? Pontia flyes away, Filamor falls at the feet of Adolph.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Yes, cruel Caesarina,
But he might have surviv'd this fatal hour,
Had'st thou been kind.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Had I been fortunate,
But I was Mistress neither of my Love,
Nor Fortune: the Gods govern'd that and me.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Pray let me weep Filamor's Obsequies, He puts by his Sister.
He was my Friend.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: He was, thou best of Sisters; and methinks
There should be virtue in thy lips to kiss him
Alive again: but if he liv'd, thy kisse
Would kill him, cruell, cruell Caesarina,
Thou hast no title to him.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: More then you,
He was my honour's and my life's preserver.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And would you not, if he could live now, love
So brave a man?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: They who dispose our Wills,
Left it not in my pow'r to grain him love.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: A Surgeon! call a Surgeon for the Prince!
Here comes one that has skill inn Surgery,
Good Fromund, search your noble Master's wound.
No hope?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: No fear; 'twas but the losse of blood
That made him swoond, he lives, carry him to rest.
O Sir, your Mother's giving up the ghost,
I left her Women chafing her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I'm sure
She deserves death for murdring of her Son:
Good Fromund search Prince Adolph, for he has
A wound at heart.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: But Violinda gave it;
Come Caesarina, if our Mother were
Worse then she is, yet she's our Mother still,
Not to be cast away for want of help,
When we see how 'tis with her, I'l be dress'd
For this slight hurt, a scratch upon my breast:
But Violinda shoots into my heart
A poison'd arrow, past the Surgeon's Art. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: FIlamor slightly hurt, and did he swound?
What riddle's this?

sp.speaker: Fromund.
sp.l: 'Tis easily unriddled;
After the Villain hurt him, when he knew
That Princess Caesarina never wish'd
To meet him like a Huntsman in the Grove,
As Brianella told Prince Filamor,
Hearing that Adolph (who believ'd her Message
An Artifice us'd by his bloody Mother)
In the same Habit was upon the Place:
The wounded Prince (never considering
Himself, but fearing danger to his friend)
From the Lawne walk'd up to the Grove so fast,
That th'agitation of his Mind and Body
Caus'd such effusion of his Blood and Spirits,
As made him (when he came to embrace Adolph)
Fall in a swound at's feet: I stanch'd the blood,
And Sir, immediately your Son recover'd.

sp.speaker: Tetrick.
sp.l: Her Mask goes on,
In which you are to represent your name-sake,
The God Sylvanus: 'tis time you were dress'd,
They'r ready to begin.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Her Mask? does she
Triumph in Princes blood?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Perhaps she hopes
The pleasure of a Mask will make the Prince
Forget her malice, and her Servants say,
That when the Mask's done, she'l divulge a Secret
In which you are concern'd.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: How is't with Adolph?
Did not my Wife take him for Filamor,
And strike at her Son's heart?

sp.speaker: Fromund.
sp.l: But miss'd her aime
Miraculously; for Prince Adolph had
Princess Violinda's Picture, which he wore
In a Gold Tablet next his heart, he was
About to look on't; opening of his buttons
And stooping, comes your wife, who being deceiv'd
By's Huntsman's Suit (so like Prince Filamor's)
Stabb'd at his heart, but light upon the Gold
And did not pierce it, only her Poniard glanc'd
Upon his breast, and drew some crimson drops:
Straight he look'd up; but when she saw her hand
Imbru'd in her son's blood, she fled and fell
Dead (as we thought); but she deceiv'd us all.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Will you please to put on the Wood-God's shape;
You'l be too late, what do you study on?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Why should the Gods reprieve that guilty woman?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: The Gods themselves had not been innocent,
If they had let her die a natural death,
And scape the hand of Justice.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'l have no Mask, till Pontia's in her Grave;
Arrest her, Fromund, and when she's condemn'd
See Execution done, be sure my wife
Revive no more,

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Fear no Recovery,
My life for her death: she's a Venimons Creature;
But if she were a Viper, let me get
Her Head and Body parted once, I'l watch 'em
For ever meeting.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: In her List for Hell,
When Pontia writ my Name, I bound my self
To punish her with death for her next Treason.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Sir, your best time will be when her Mask's done,
Or else the Secret she means then to publish.
Will die with her.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: God of the Woods, Sylvanus,
Whose shape I now assume, do thou inspire me.

div.stage: Enter Pontia wearing Diana's Cressent on her head.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: If the Celestial minds had been possess'd
With such a bloody rage as fill'd my Breast,
My House had been destroy'd for my Offence:
But the Gods spar'd my Children's Innocence;
And when my Soul was frighted with her Crime,
Bound for Eternity, they gave me Time
For the recovery of Life, and Fame
(Dearer then Life) that my corrupted Name
Might be with tears purifi'd, and made fit
To grace my Tomb, when my Inscription's writ.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I sent for you, to let you know
The Gladiators were not slain; my Servant
Tells me, they fled to Barnet-Woods: I 've sent
To have them apprehended, and they shall
Be brought to Justice; now let's mind our Sport,
Which must disguise my trouble, that I may aside.
Give Filamor an opportunity:
Diana's Cressent to a nobler end
Was never worn; Goddesse of Chastity
Assist the God of Love, shout from thy Bow
His Arrow into Caesarina's Heart.
Dear Caesarina, you are dress'd, stay here
And thank Prince Filamor.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: I shall obey you;
But Madam, I beseech you, why am I
Enjoyn'd to give him thanks? do you suspect,
That I'm inclining to ingratitude?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: No: But your Gratitude at this time, may
Dispose him to forgive my Cruelty,
Which strikes into my Heart the very Poniard
I aym'd at his.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: That Question makes me fear, that you your self
Believe not my Repentance; 'tis no more
Then I am to expect from all the World.
But ere the Hour-glass, that's now turn'd, runs out,
I hope to satisfie that general Doubt.
He's here, the God of Marriage bless their Meeting.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: What Nymph's this? tis not Caesarina, sure,
Though it presents her divine form? 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Heark, she calls me Filamor!
But am I Filamor? do I see and hear?
Nay, do I live? has not the Villain slain me?
And is not that bless'd Form, inherent in
My Soul, descended with it to the Shades?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: No, Filamor lives, a Sacrifice of Thanks
For the Pantheon in which all the Gods
Are worship'd, whose united Pow'rs preserv'd
Your Valour, that redeem'd my Life and Honour,
An Obligation (past acknowledgment)
For which I wish you all you can desire—

sp.speaker: Fil,
sp.p: How I am ravish'd with Celestial Musique!

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Oh, that Clause has spoil'd
The fairest Evidence that was ever drawn
For the intitling of a Lover's Faith
To his sweet Hope.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Valiant Prince Filamor,
Cast away that effeminate vain Hope,
And think of noble Objects, Spoils and Triumphs.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Great Actions, Madam, are for happy men,
But misery designs my Arms to Rust,
My Glory to the Urne that holds my Dust:
I see, you do not love me,

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: More Sir, more
Then you do love your self; for if I might
Dispose of your Successes, Filamor
Should, like young Alexander, conquer all
The World, but Caesarina; there's your Friend;
Now Company comes in, I take leave of you. Exitura.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: And I must bid adieu to Happiness.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Yet this my brave Preserver may believe,
If I'd subject my self to any man,
Filamor should be Lord of Caesarina. Exit Caesarina.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And so thou shalt, I'l pass my word; and then
You may be the Insurer of my Mistress:
For as the great Ship towes the little Cock-boat,
My Sister towes thy Sister after her.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Which presages well,
Now sit, and let's see, if Diana's Mask
Be no worse than Apollo's; What sayes th'Authour?

div.stage: Enter Pontia, as Diana; Caesarina as Flora; Brianella as Progne.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: Goddess of Flowr's, though you have still
Narcissus in your Daffadil,
I fear you'l lose him by degrees;
My Brother dis-inchants the Trees;
Birds I restore; some other Powers
May un-metamorphose Flowers.

sp.speaker: Caesarina.
sp.l: Diana, the fair Huntresse, knowes
She may my Flowr's and Me dispose.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Come hither Flora, do you know
This blushing Lady?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: You have forgot her; so had I:
When, lo, I saw a Swallow fly
O're London, to my Temple-top,
Then to the ground she seems to drop.
But in her fall spreading her wings,
Flyes to my Altar, sits and sings;
Her voice I know, and that she mourn'd
For her lost Form, which I return'd;
The Swallow's Progne once agen.

sp.speaker: Brianel.
sp.l: And shall be happy Progne, when
My Sister Philomel I see;
I hear her in that Hawthorn-tree: The Nightingale sings in a Hawthorn Bush.
Diana, pitty her sweet sorrow.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My Grove, thy Nightingale I'l borrow,
She shall be now Diana's Creature,
I'l joyn her Honour to her Feature.
A Maid the second time I'l make her;
Back back my Moons, and overtake her
An hour before that sad dishonour
Thy husband (Progne) forc'd upon her.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: He was a Villain; yet that shape Violinda, as Philomel, appears in the Hawthorn, & sings.
Might tempt a God to act a Rape.

sp.speaker: Violinda.
sp.l: How my Rape was brought about,
And how my Tongue cut out,
I need not tell,
'Tis known as well
As my woful name of Philomel,
Which, though my speech did fail,
My Soul did so bewail,
That it throbb'd into a Nightingale.
Then I, poor Bird,
Had Tongue, but not a Word;
I sung, but could not speak:
As if my heart would break
Warbled I.
But no more Revenge I cry,
Now the Ravisher's acquitted;
For, Diana's mighty pow'r
Calls back this the happy'st Hour,
The Hour before the Crime committed.

div.stage: As Philomel comes down from the Hawthorn Tree, a Satyr leaps out of a Bush, and catches the hem of her Vest.

sp.speaker: Satyr.
sp.l: Twice a Maid
And both times betray'd:
Your Virginity's private Grant
Must be sung
With your new tongue,
To inveigle a young Gallant?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: I can assure you,
Goats are ravishers by Nature;
But I love, let that secure you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Satyr, our Inclinations meet;
Let's dance.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: No; I'm too much below you,
My antique tricks I dare not show you,
Diana so affects Sobriety, Enter Sylvanus, as the God Sylvanus, after him 3. other Wood-Gods▪
Th'old Wood-God dances with her Deity;
For you three God Sylvanus brings
Gods of the Copses, Groves and Springs;
But though you are above my levell,
Yet through a Bush I'l see you revell.

lg.head: Chorus.
lg.l: But we still please our fancies:

stage.hi: The four Gods dance with the four Ladies.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: The Satyr acts the Roman To Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Yes, I made aside.
Princess Violinda Philomel, to mind
Th'old Prince of's wife's barbarity to's daughter.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: By the Princessse
The Company's desir'd to stay, and hear
What she'l discover for the Publick Good.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Perhaps she may build Temples,
Now that she's in the habit of a Goddesse.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: When she does any Good, Publick or Private,
Let none think that I'm vers'd in both the Globes,
If th'Earth does not rise up, or the Skie fall.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Justice and Truth compel me to reveal
A Secret, which Discretion would conceal:
But I'l reveal it to no private Ear;
All are concen'd, and therefore all shall hear.
If any think it stange, that I express
My serious thoughts in such a fained Dress,
Know, since by his sad fate your Prince was curs't
To marry me, this Habit is the first
In which I've done no mischief; Treason stains
My Princely Robes: and if my Hand retains
The native whiteness, tis not that I'm Good,
But that I could not take the dye of Blood.
So foul as I never had Woman been,
Had but my Pow'r been equal to my Spleen:
My Husband's life I did to Hell devote,
Malice, which Hell it self would not promote;
But the just wrath of Heav'n turn'd my Design
Laid against him and his, on me and mine;
To murder Violinda, Rogues I hir'd,
To ravish Caesarina they Conspir'd;
And when I thought a Dagger to have struck
In Filamor, at Adolph's Heart I stuck.
Who would be wicked? when the very Crime
