Conceiv'd, torments our Souls, and at the time
When 'tis deliver'd, like an Engin broke,
Destroys us with the force of our own stroke.
Forgive me all that bear a Prince's Name,
The glorious Title which sets off my shame;
And you, dear Pledges of my Lord's first Bed,
With mercy look upon the tears I shed;
Now that you see my traitors Offence
Wash'd in these streams of Publick Penitence;
In one Orb let us near Relations move,
Forget my Hatred, and embrace my Love.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The Devil, out of all his Languages,
Could not pick words more moving.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Yet they work not,
The Prince sits still.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Though she stands up to Court him.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: If any man believes the secret of
The Princess's Repentance, let him speak.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Their very silence has pronounc'd her door.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: The hope of comfort adds but to my grief,
For I see, all I say finds no belief;
But when in Charge against my self I bring
Facts out of which your fears and dangers spring;
You'l answer, what security affords,
The soft contexture of a few good words;
I grant, they rather may your Fears increase,
And therefore I'l give Hostages of Peace:
My Adolph bound in Love's eternal Bands,
I'l render into Violinda's Hands;
And Filamor (by sacred Hymen's leave)
Shall Caesarina from my hand receive.
sp.stage: Pontia rises, and goes to joyn their hanas.
sp.l: Come Caesarina, give the Prince your self.

sp.speaker: Caesarina.
sp.l: From me what is not due to Filamor,
Who, with his life in's hand, rescu'd my Honour?

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.p: Did not I prophesy? dear Filamor?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: The Prince, in lieu of his, may claim my Life,
But not my Slavery; I'l be no man's Wife.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.l: Doye hear Adolph?
Now who's the Prophet?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Thou art— the blind Prophet;
I am the Seer; they are ours as sure
As we are theirs— Sylvanus sits down in the Chair of State.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I'l try another Speech—
Ha! who presumes to take my place? what's he?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: A Judge, bound by his oath, when he hears Treason
Confess'd, to doom the Parricide to death.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: No Judge shall doom me, but the Prince my Husband.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Behold the Husband to whom you appeal,
A Judge, bound by the honour of my word,
When you first sought my life, that if you ever
Committed a new Treason, you should die:
There needs no form of Law, from your own mouth
A clowd of Witnesses have prov'd your Treason;
Nor will we torture you with hearing it
Repeated, nor with your accursed blood
Will we prophane Diana's sacred Grove.
Be it decreed, That in the Lawne, the place
Where by thy Gladiators Violinda
Should have been murder'd, thou shalt lose thy head.
A guard: away with her, but give her time
(So it exceed not half an hour) to pray.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Vengeance is slow, but certain. I have vext
This World too long, dispatch me to the next.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Doubt nothing Adolph, I'l secure her life:
Tetrick, you have too far ingag'd my Father,
'Twas never my intention, she should die.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: 'Tis your own business, you may do't your way
And save her life, that she may ruine you.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Nay I would have her out of hope to live,
That she may really repent, but then
Dear Tetrick (thou command'st the Guards) reprieve her:
Do't at my perill.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: I am like to do it
At my own peril too; but I'l obey you.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Come friend, and as we go, tell Caesarina To Adolph
How careful I am to preserve your Mother.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Fromund and Brianella.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: What a strange Monster your great Mistress is,
That neither her son nor her daughter open
Their lipps for her?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: But do you think she'l die?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Unless she has, like Nile, more Heads then one,
One head's condemn'd, I'l see't cut off, your servant.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: But heark you Fromund; I took you to be
An honest man.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Troth, 'tis no sign of exc'lent honesty
To profess love to me, and in a time
Of danger leave me to my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Why?
Are you in any danger?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Then you know not
I was my Lady's Coy-duck, to bring in
Prince Filamor?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Pish! a poor little Treason,
They'l never mind you, now they've got the Princess.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: This all the care you take for her that loves you?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I understand not loving; will you marry?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Then I'l secure you.
But will you not break promise when you'r safe?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No, I hate baseness; I have lov'd you long,
But I'm so bashful, I should scarce have own'd it,
If this unlucky occasion had not offer'd
It self.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I have caught you now.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: No (drown you) you'l scape th'halter,
That falls to our shares; but no matter what
Becomes of us: Sylvanus—

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Lost! all's lost, Pontia rescu'd, we are now
Her Slaves.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Hear, and wonder:
We came into the Lawne; and though 'twas meant
Pontia should live, she knew't not, but compos'd
Her self to die, so mildly, that it struck
Into astonishment all the beholders;
Such a dead stilnesse was upon the place,
'Twas like a Sea becalm'd; when, in an instant,
The Storm breaks forth, thund'ring came Pontia's Horse,
And in the head of them her Gen'rall Crispus:
Our Guards (amaz'd before) now as if they
Had seen in th'Enemies shields the Gorgon's head
(Which had the petrifying quality)
Turn'd Statues; stood still, whilst the Maldeners
Bound them; and Crispus, like young Perseus,
Releas'd the condemn'd Princesse, seiz'd the Prince.
And Principality of Verulam:
They took me Pris'ner, but the General
(When he was told my Name, remembering
He had read my Book of Fortification)
Freed me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Then we may live to free our Masters;
Nay, we may speak Treason before this Lady;
She has promis'd me marriage.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Since when, pray?
I'l be judg'd by this learned Gentleman;
You said, that marrying was loving; I
Answer'd, that I would love you; but I hope
I did not say, that I would marry you:
Alas, poor Fool; O brave, brave General!

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: The General's the Man, and I'm the Fool; aside.
You will not have me?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: But though in point of Love you have deceived me,
Upon th' account of Gratitude; I hope
You'l beg my life?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: That's all you have to beg,
Y' have neither Lands nor Goods; but I'm too rich
To be a Beggar upon any score.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: To save your Life, I would have ventur'd mine,

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: But your simplicity's no rule for me;
In sober sadness, I will never marry
You, nor espouse your Danger: So adieu,
Kind younger Brother, do what you were born to;
Shift for your self: O brave, brave General!

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Come Fromund, follow me, I know the Woods,
I'l lead thee to a place of sweet recesse,
Where we'l enjoy our selves, and never think
Of Women more.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: But rise up Bard and Driud.
Farewel Philosophers, and welcome General.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: Command in our Name, upon pain of death,
That none presume to pillage, or take Pris'ner
Any of my Subjects of Verulam,
Unless that Subject desperately rebel,
And put his Country in Blood

sp.speaker: Brianella.
sp.l: O Heav'n!
And have I liv'd to see my Princely Mistresse
Soveraign of Verulam?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My Soveraignty
And Life I owe to my Lord General.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What Virgin would not love so brave a man?
Madam, Remember now your gracious Promise,
And move the General for me.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Your best time
Will be when business of the War is over;
For, Marriages are businesses of Peace.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: O Madam, when your Highness was concern'd,
I put not you off to a better time.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: If you'l not take advise, then take your Fortune;
My Lord, you know this Lady?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That she's the richest
In all your Principality of Malden;
In all your Court of Verulam the greatest,
For she's your Fav'rite.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: She would be your wife;
I have ingag'd to use my pow'r with you—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Not to make her my wife? y'are not in earnest?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: And so am I,
Never to marry a Property.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: A Property for Murder, was not she
Us'd for the intrapping of Prince Filamor?
Madam, to me you made another Promise,
By which you are oblig'd to banish her.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My word's past, so's her greatness: Brianella,
If to our Court thou com'st after this day,
Thou dy'st.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: But I may see your Husband dye
Before I go; then, I hope, you'l perform
Your other Promise to the General;
For, it seems, you have promis'd him your self;
Give you Joy— of my Curses, I've one day aside.
Yet left to curse you; hang me, if I pray. Exit Brian.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My Fav'rite's banish'd; now Sir do you think
That I'l perform my Promise?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: If you were
A real Convert, of your own accord
You would have banish'd all such Instruments,

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I have been so long wicked, that no man
Will credit my Repentance, but distrust
From Crispus wounds me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Why then (I beseech you)
Do y' keep your Husband and his Children Pris'ners?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Why are you so presumptious as to ask?
Who made you our Examiner? your duty
Is to attend, till we declare our self.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Bid the Groom bring my Horses to the Gate.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Believe't I'l sooner part with my new Conquest;
After you were commanded to withdraw,
My Promise being debated, 'twas resolv'd
Upon the Question, that you should be still
My Favorite.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Great hope of her amendment. aside.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Sir, you shall now have proof of our Repentance,
Call in the Pris'ners. Exit Crispus.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: To restore me to
Your favour, was the General consenting?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: He hates thee, as I hate him, mortally.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Poorly; thou shalt see him crush'd
To his first Nothing.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Mighty General,
'Twill elevate my Soul to see thy Fall:
There is a Pleasure in Revenge, above
The expectation or the joyes of Love.
And to revenge my selve on thee, is just;
But the betraying of Prince Filamor, aside.
Who never injur'd me, was base: Some power
That, as I do, pities that noble Prince,
Put it into her Heart, to spare his life
One hour, and I'l make use of her new Favour
To expiate my Crime; I'l now Charm Her,
And free him from his cruel Step-Mother.

div.stage: Enter Adolph, Caesarina, Crispus, Sylvanus, Filamor, Violinda and the Guard. Pontia sits.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Old man, who hast outliv'd Humanity,
From me what can'st expect?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: What thou deserv'st,
Death: death, to which my Justice sentenc'd thee,
I do expect now from thy Cruelty;
And I'l meet th'axe with such a Resolution
As shall (if thou dar'st be a looker on)
Shake thy weak Soul into another Swound.
Though I liv'd under thy Reign like a Waman,
Yet I'l die like a Man.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Since you'r so brave,
I'l not take pattern by your former baseness;
For, Sir, when I was to have lost my head,
No state was thought upon, no Princes order'd
To follow me; You shall have Filamor
And Violinda to bear up your train.
Between your Sentence and my Execution,
Your wither'd narrow heart could afford me
But half an hour; I'l give you a whole hour.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Bountiful wife, you are extream obliging.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: My Pray'r is heard, I'l now serve Filamor. aside.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Better than Life,
'Tis Nature's greater bounty, for we may
Improve it to an immortality
Of Fame, by dying nobly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I have liv'd
By Caesarina's rule, by yours I'l dye.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Oh, name not dying; though my Mother has
Condemn'd you, yet Heav'n cannot be so cruell.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Capito take you charge of the old man,
And my Lord Gen'rall to your Custody,
We do commit his Children.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Here's Reward
For all my Services, I am preferr'd
To th'Office of a Marshall.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: May we two
With your permission, my Lord Generall,
Speak with your Pris'ners?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: At your pleasure, Sir:
For, as to that, I am not limited,
And I'l put no Restraint upon my self.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: You ever were a Person of great honour.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Therefore in this base Charge my Shame's the more;
To serve my Prince I never blush'd before. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Pontia sitting, and writing the Superscription of a Letter; Brianella standing by her, on the Table lyes a Parchment.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: FOr taking of the Pris'ners from the Generall,
That Letter to Prince Adolph I procur'd,
Which shews there is a justice in my nature,
I hope 'twill save the life of Filamor
Whom I wrong'd: and I'm sure 'twill take away
The last remainder of his Trust from Crispus,
Who wrong'd me— my Lord Generall Capito,
The Princesse call'd for you: he minds uot me?
I have no fortune to these Generalls.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: My Lord, you'r rais'd to the command in chief
Over our Forces, by obeying us.

sp.speaker: Capito.
sp.l: Madam, my Will is vassal to your Pleasure,
You are my Gen'rall, not to be ask'd, Why,
But What you please; and that I'l do, or die.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: First, show to Crispus your Commission,
And vacate his: then take you charge of th'Army,
Which we design'd you two hours since, when he
Gave rules to us, but I was forc'd to use him,
Till to this height he rais'd my Soveraignty.
Now Verulam is ours, the Building's finish'd,
And we'l take down the Scaffolds.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Such a fall aside.
May all the proud Men have, who scorn kind Women.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: In the last place, double your Guards, that we
May prevent suddain tumults, and attempts
In favour of the condemn'd Princes, they
(I doubt) have Parties in our Camp and Court;
But were it in our own veins they should bleed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Without distinction, whos'ere lifts his hand
Against your pow'r, shall feel the weight of mine.
Please to dismiss me, that I be not straiten'd
In point of time?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Go, and be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Fortune, my Goddess, is great Pontia's hand-maid.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I forgot one particular; I'l send
This Lady to you, when she comes, do you
Return, and bring Crispus to us.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I shall. Exit Capito.

div.stage: Pontia gives the Letter to Brianella.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: There Brianella, I have writ to Adolph
As you desir'd, I can deny you nothing;
But yet to trust my Son with custody
Of Violinda and Filamor (the Prince
Being my Son's Friend, the Princess his Mistris,
(Should Love against his Interest byass him)
May be of dangerous consequence.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Prince Adolph,
To preserve them, will not lose Verulam.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I see Brianella is for Filamor: aside.
Well, I will venture't, upon your account,
Though Adolph may deceive me.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I hope he will. aside.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Give him that Letter, in which is inclos'd
A discharge of our latest trust to Crispus.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Then Crispus (whether bound for Heav'n or Hell)
She, whom you scorn'd, shall toul your passing Bell.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Away, leave me to perfect my own story;
I'l add to my two Crowns a third of Glory.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.l: We have out-walk'd the General and my Sister;
Let's tarry for them?

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.l: By no means, least Fate
Should overtake you; th' Executioner
Is setting up your Scaffold: Filamor
Stands now upon the Verge of Life and Death;
Here is a Grave, and there's a Sanctuary:
Behind that Hedge I've laid for you a Horse,
A Fleeter's not in Britain; mount him, fly.

sp.speaker: Caesarina.
sp.l: As for your noble Sister and your Father,
(When once my Mother knows that you'r escap'd)
She will not dare to touch them; fly.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: How? fly?
You heard the General take my Parol,
And would my Friends have me to save my Life
Lose th'end for which Man lives, Honour?

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: O Sir,
Under the notion of a private man
Consider not your self, on you depend.
Thousands of Subjects Lives.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And a whole race
Of unborn Princes.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: To preserve Mankind,
I'd not break my Ingagement; though till now
I never valu'd life, yet when 'tis offer'd
By those I prize above life, I am bound
In honour to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: 'Tis too late Enter Crispus and Violinda.
To pass now; here's your Keeper, but I'l make
Way through him with my sword, I'l fight with Crispus.

sp.speaker: Violinda.
sp.l: I hope you'l not fight with the Generall
That uses us with such Civility,
'Tis Pontia, not Crispus, that condemn'd us;
And we had rather suffer death, than you
Should rescue us with hazard of your life.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: First let me move him: My Lord Generall,
Fame gives you such a noble Character,
That I can't think you a willing Instrument
In the injustice done to these two Princes.

sp.speaker: Crispus.
sp.l: Madam, to shew how my Obedience
Has been constrain'd to act against my Will,
If an exchange of Lives may be admitted,
I'l die to excuse them.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: That you may do,
And not die, only wink at their Escape-

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No, then my Honour dyes.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Honour and Fortune
Shall recompence that Piety.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: More Titles
Than Caesar claimes, and all the sparkling Gold
Into the Sea with ebbing Tagus roll'd,
Cannot buy me out of a sacred Trust:
Poor Crispus may be, but he will be just.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Crispus, with a Friend's arm I could embrace thee,
Were not thy worth destructive to my Friends;
But now I'l meet thee as an enemy.
sp.stage: As Adolph offers to draw, Enter Capito and Souldiers.
sp.l: Capito? what newes?

sp.speaker: Capito.
sp.l: Such as does amaze
The Messenger, that Parchment will inform
You, my Lord Generall.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I kiss her Name Enter Brianella.
That sign'd it, and so vanishes my power;
'Tis Capito's the Generall: Have y' Order
To take the pris'ners from me?

sp.speaker: Brianella.
sp.l: That's my Office;
For I bring up the rear of your Discharges,
This is your last: but this you'r will'd to leave
Your Pris'ners with Prince Adolph.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Then these are
My last Commands?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: No; we two must attend
The Princess, after we have view'd the Army.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: My Lord, I'l wait on you, as cheerfully
As ever I charg'd with you.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Go thy way
In quiet; though I long, I have no power
To insult o're thee, thou'rt so brave a man:
But to my business: humbly at your feet, She kneels.
Prince Filamor, I beg your pardon, for
The impudent abuse I put on You
To please my Mistresse: but to make my self
Capable of your mercy, I've us'd all
My interest with her to get that Letter
Which trusts you and your Sister to your Friend;
Your Mother thought it dangerous, but my power
With her, prevail'd against her Reason.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Rise,
For what your Prince commands, you may be excus'd,
I'm satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: So am not I, to see
My Mother's favour thus misplac'd on thee:
Out of my sight; were not Women, like Priests,
Exempted from the power of the sword,
I would have ki'lld thee.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: It had been but Justice,
I do deserve to die, and I deserve not
To be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Come Princes, I'l not trust you
Out of my hands till I have lodg'd you safe.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Then you must see them out of Verulam
Within this half hour. Exit Brianella.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: This goes to my Mother; To Filamor.
But my Friend and my Love shall go with me.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.p: We'l all be pris'ners, or we'l all be free.

div.stage: Enter Tetrick as the Conjurer; and Fromund with the Bard's Beard in his hand.

sp.speaker: Tetrick.
sp.l: Once more I'm the mock-Conjurer, the Gods
Or else the devill take her that's the cause on't!
Another Devil take mock-Prophecies,
They prove so true: when I made the Bard's Song,
Who would have thought those canting words should prove
An Oracle?

sp.speaker: Fromund.
sp.l: I'l be the Bard to purpose;
For, Tetrick, in these Fortune-telling Shapes,
As mighty Pontia's Prophets we shall passe
The regiment drawn up to guard the Scaffold.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Then if the Generall scape my dagger, he
Shall have Prince Adolph's luck, but Crispus is not
So well bred as to wear a Lady's Picture
Next to his heart.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Strike home I'l second thee;
By my hand the Lievtenant-Generall falls:
Prince Adolph may then be the Generall,
And he'l protect the Prices: what becomes
Of thee and me, no matter.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: As I live, Enter Brianella.
Thy Mistris, coming hither, do thou slip
Behind these Bushes; as I promis'd thee,
I'l dispatch thy love business, if w'have time

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No, they'r safe in
Prince Adolph's hands, that one good deed I've done.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Then to the Bard's Cave you are kindly welcome;
(Now I may fool a little) what's your pleasure? aside.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Is the good Woman here, she that tells fortunes?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: You mean my pretty Mistris, the old Witch;
She's riding on her distaff into Lapland,
(To morrow being our Wedding-day) to fetch
Her Gemmes, and all her Parafarnalia:
Before she set forth, she commanded me,
I should examine all the Stars that shin'd
At your Nativity, for a Generall
To be your husband: take't upon my word,
The Planets know not any Generall
That loves you.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I hate Generalls, can you tell
My husband's name?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Ill news I'l tell you, Madam;
My reverend Spouse went away in a whirlwind;
Poor heart, the saddest soul; you'l hardly guess
What griev'd her, the losse of your Saphyr-Ring,
For which I set a figure, and t'appears
Your Ring was lost by a strange providence,
For he that finds it is to be your Husband.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What if I like him not?

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: You'l only be
Torn in a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: If he be
Of the malignant party, or a rebell,
You shall tear me into a thousand pieces
Before I marry him.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: The man that found it
(For now 'tis found) is of the Loyal Party.

sp.speaker: Fromund.
sp.l: Madam, I think, you dropt this Saphyr-ring?
I saw you passe, and strove to over-take you:
You were too nimble for me; but I kiss'd
The ground you trod upon, and there lay this.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: 'Twas mine, 'tis yours, keep't, I'l take nothing from you
Which Fortune gives you.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Though it be her self;
And (as the mouth of fortune) I pronounce,
'Tis so; come, let me joyn your hands in Marriage:
Now you are Man and Wife; I leave the rest
For night, if we out-live this day, that looks
So black on Verulam, and our great Masters.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: But the Magician is Pontia's Creature.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Madam; do you know me?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Yes faith, I was th'old Witch, an't please you Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Oh you'r rare Fortune-telling youths! but we
Are soon perswaded to a thing we like:
For if I had not lov'd you—

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: And I you;
I would not have marry'd another Lady.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nor would I've had another younger brother.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: On, on; the Princes have imployment for us?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: And We have Lives for them.

div.stage: Enter Adolph, Filamor, Caesarina, Violinda, and a Footman.

sp.speaker: Adolph.
sp.p: Our horses are now come, I'l be your Conyoy.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.p: You shall not give your self that dangerous trouble.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I'l see you safe, out of my Mother's power.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Then you must see us die, for that determines
Your Mother's pow'r.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Why do you make a halt?
What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I mean to go no further;
Filamor is now at his Journey's end,
Here I'l lay down the burden of my life,
And rest.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Defend me! this is such a Madness,
That 'tis infectious, it distracts me too;
Will you stay, till your last hour be run out?
Will you be accessary (not alone
To your own death, but) to the murder of
Your Father, and your Sister?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Should I scape
By a base flight, my Father's age would fall
At Pontia's feet a bleeding Sacrifice:
Forgive me, Sister; for thy tender Youth
My heart bleeds through my eyes. Filamor weeps.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Do not afflict
Your self for me; the World is full of Ladies,
And I shall not be miss'd in that great Crowd:
But howsoever, when you go to find
Another World, I would not stay behind.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Do y' pitty her sweet youth? and are y'unmov'd
With her mind's bravery? how easily
Will you leave us? he takes Caesarina by the hand.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: As the soul leaves the body;
Forc'd to it by fatall necessity:
For a memorial of my love, I make you
My Heirs, between you divide Verulam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Let a Sea-breach (to quench thy Funeral Fire)
Swallow up Verulam, and Malden first:
But whence comes this fatall necessity?
You think to fly, is base? who ever stood
More upon honour then th'old Romans? yet,
After his Cimbrian Triumph, Marius fled
And begg'd near conquer'd Carthage; you shall live
Like a Prince still.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I must not live at all;
And better die by the hand of Injustice,
Then by my own hand: in a word, I'm barr'd
From my love, and I'l not accept my life.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Do y'hear this, Caesarina? now you know,
Your resolution is the cause of his;
He will not live, because you will not love him:
Though Filamor might live long, if my Sister
Were not more barbarous to him than my Mother:
For she's his enemy, death from her must be
Expected: You, his friend, may get him off,
And yet you leave him to his enemy's mercy.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Farwell, brave Filamor; a point is started
Which makes me take my leave.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You shall not go;
Though for my own life I was not concern'd,
Yet, Caesarina, for my brother's safety
I must petition you.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: Move not a Suit,
I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Can you not grant one Suit,
To save two Lives?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Nay Sister, you may go:
But yet, remember, he, you leave to die,
Rescu'd your honour.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible,
I can preserve his life without destroying
My own contentment; therefore, Filamor,
Your interest has the preference, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: I am I know not what, my Joy's so vast,
It puts an Army's strength into my nerves.
To horse, to horse, I'l bear this Prize away
Through Groves of Pikes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Stay, stay till I be ready;
I'l not fight, till Violinda gives the word:
Madam, you know, I had your gracious promise,
When she was his Wife, that you would be mine?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Well Adolph, by her copy I'm your wife:
But Sir, if she had not been forc'd to render,
I would have held out, till I had been older
And wiser, for I understand not Love.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Dear Madam, I'l instruct you— now let's charge—

sp.speaker: Tetrick.
sp.l: Your Mistresses; this Coupling-time's the death
Of more Wild-fowl then all the Year besides;
Look, here's another pair, of Widgeons, catch'd,
And I am in the Net for company:
Th' Army has hedg'd— about the Grove, one Passe
Is only open, at which we came in.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.p: No matter; Hannibal wrought through the Rock.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Our Swords are sharper then his Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.p: Yet, my young Hannibals, pray, view your danger?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Come, He offers to kiss Violinda.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I'd only kiss my heart into more courage.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Speak softly, Sir, for fear your Mother hear you,
And then, you will be chid abominably. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Pontia, Capito, Crispus, and Officers of the Army.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: Crispus, you see, your Greatness, like our Coin,
Ev'n when 'twas Yours was Ours; wee've call'd it in
As a base Mettal, that dishonours us.

sp.speaker: Crispus.
sp.p: I'm what you please, but only—

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Yet will you own the Justice of my Cause,
And act in the reducing of the Pris'ners,
And th'Army for their Generall shall own you?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: First, do like Xerxes, cut me into halves:
Then lay me, where the moving Army may
March through their Generall.

sp.speaker: Capito.
sp.l: Take Crispus to your Custody, admit
None to speak with him. Exit Crispus guarded.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Yet your Emissaries
May be deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: One in a tree (close by them)
Saw them joyn hands.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: It seems they'r marry'd then,
Yet since Adolph's ingag'd, I'd have them taken
Without a drop of blood.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: That cannot be,
Unless we send out more Spyes to discover,
Before the Princes come to fight, what place
They leave the Ladies in: If they be taken,
Adolph and Filamor will lay down their arms,
As I shall work it.

div.stage: Enter Filamor, Caesarina, Adolph, Violinda, Fromund, Brianella, and Tetrick.

sp.speaker: Tetrick.
sp.l: None believes my Predictions but your Mother;
You'r in a Pound now, get out as you may.

sp.speaker: Filamor.
sp.l: The Passe, at which you came, is slightest guarded,
Let's break out there.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: In the Bard's Cave, for there they will be safe,

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Your Mother has a reverence for the place,
She'l violate a Temple e're she'l take e'm
Out of that Cave.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: The Counsell is not ill;
To the Bard's Cave we'l wait upon our Loves,
If we break through, we'l send for you at night:
But if the Army comes in to Prince Adolph,
We'l see you presently.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: And if we fall,
(Nay, weep not, Dear) we will have company
Into the Stars, if the rogues go not downward.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis only Multitudes that I'm afraid of.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: When Filamor fights, I can fear no odds,
His Cause is Honour's, Love's, and all the Gods.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.p: Your Spyes are not come in?

sp.speaker: Capito.
sp.l: They've had no time Capito pulls out a Letter, and two Purses.
For a discovery yet: do y' know these,
Madam?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: The Jewells which I gave the Gladiators.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: One would think, you sprung from that fortunate King,
Whose Jewells, lost at Sea, came to his Table
Serv'd up i'th belly of a Fish.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Where are
The Villains?

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: This account the Letter gives:
Barnet- Woods were laid for them; by your Order:
Our Souldiers follow'd, and came up so close;
The rogues, for their last refuge, were constrain'd
To imitate Merchants in a storm, who save
Themselves, by casting over-board their Treasure:
So, emptying into their hands these purses,
They sew'd th'unplough'd Earth with your Gold and Jewells;
And whil'st our covetous men gather'd them up,
The Gladiators fled; and here's your Own.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: And they have their reward, a fearful Judgment;
Their Lives are sav'd, but their Livelihood's lost,
And that's more horrid then the death they fear'd;
For in this Isle they dare not stay, nor dare they
Go to the Continent, lest their Countrymen
(Who command there) should hang them; they must starve.
sp.stage: Enter a Spie, and whispers Capito.
sp.l: You look as if we had our wish, what news?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How infinitely fortunate are you,
The Ladies in the Bard's Cave are secur'd.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: My men have orders;
The Princesses shall be brought in, to face
The Princes, there they come; I will amuze them
Till the work's done.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: They shall not see me yet. Pontia goes aside.

div.stage: Enter Filamor, Adolph, Tetrick and Fromund, with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: Princes, what means this fury, that you brave
With a few hands the strength of a whole Army?
Pray, tell me, what do you rely upon,
Your selves? or others? do y' look for Assistance?
It must come down from heav'n, and there dwells none
That will assist a Son against a Mother: He points to Filamor.
Nor will heav'n own a Cause it has deserted?
With Adolph Nature's angry, and the Gods
With Filamor: If to your selves you trust,
Reason will tell you, four before four thousand
Must fall to th'Earth's cold arms, from whence they sprung:
So that you only can expect to have
From Heav'n a Thunderbolt, from th' Earth a Grave.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: Hold Filamor, Capito gives the sign to the Centree, and then Sylvanus is brought in by an Executioner.
If you have no compassion for your self,
Look on the snow that lyes uponthat head,
Which must be taken off, at the first blow
You strike.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Filamor, if thou pitty'st me,
Strike quickly, and let me die, any death,
So I may be rid of my wife, I care not.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: Poor Prince, the Grief to see his Son so wilful,
Distracts him.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: If he will not hold his prating,
Cut his throat, Filamor; charge them, that my Soul
May have her liberty, a thousand blessings
Upon the hand, that fighting moves this Engine
To strike my head off and divorce me from
My brutish wife.

div.stage: As the Princes are coming on, the Princesses are discovered under a Guard in the, Bard's Cave.

sp.speaker: Capi.
sp.l: Hold, once more; Princes take heed what y do
How showes this Object? Pontia shewes her self.

sp.speaker: Pontia.
sp.l: Yes, Filamor; she that was once my child,
Is now my pris'ner: when she marry'd thee,
I disclaim'd her: I look upon her now
As on a Rebell, yet her life I'l pardon,
If you lay down your Arms.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Immediately,
A Roman would not pause in such a Case.

div.stage: He turns his Sword on his own Breast.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: If you but offer at your life, she dyes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Friend, there's no struggling against Fate, give me
Thy Sword; There Capito, with my own I render
Prince Filamor's Arms, he shall not kill himself,
Let's Enemy do that office, I'l wait on him.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: So, now I'm all that I can wish to be;
O 'tis the Queen of all Felicities
To have full pow'r to reward and revenge.
Bring the late General Crispus, that I may Crispus guarded.
At one time cut off all my Enemies.
First, Filamor, to you— I give my Daughter;
To your Sister my Son, and to my Son
I give my Principality of Malden,
For I'l depend only upon my husband:
For whose pardon and love thus low I beg.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Rely on me, and you'l be a good Wife,
Then I shall study to forget your Evill,
And love you for your Goodness.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: With my thanks
For this inestimable Guift, I crave
Your pardon for my incredulity
When you return'd to Virtue.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: That distrust
Was universall, for which all have suffer'd;
And yet thus far I would not have pursued
Th'advantage fortune put into my hands,
But that I knew nothing could bring my Daughter
To Love's obedience, but the hope to save
His life who sav'd her honour: To give her
That opportunity, I committed you
Both Pris'ners to your Friend.

sp.speaker: Cae.
sp.l: I am bound to you
For my conversion to Love's Deity.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Adolph, for thee I have a second Guift,
But greater then the first; into thy service
And (nearer yet) into thy bosome take
This man of honour, thoroughly I've She presents Crispus to Adolph. him,
He's perfect, use him, and he'l make thee Great.
Let him be Captain Generall of thy Army,
And give the Second Place to Capito,
Whose strict Obedience and prudent Conduct,
Makes him inferiour to none but Crispus.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Now Pontia, like the Planet of the Night,
Breaks from her clowd, and shews us her pure light.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Though one Prince limits my Obedience,
Two Sovereigns my bosome does contain,
For in my heart Adolph and Pontia reign.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Me and my love you've crown'd, and added these
Two rich Crown-jewels. He embraces Crispus and Capito.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I'm oblig'd to you
Both for my interest in the Crown and Prince.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Fromund, I joy you; and I'l move my husband
To add a Title of Honour to your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Well, you are a Witch,
You told me, I should be Right Honourable.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Tetrick, to make you a Fortune, take this gold
And Jewells.

sp.speaker: Tet.
sp.l: Nay, since Fortune smiles upon me,
I'l not be testy now: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Let us all thank Providence, that directs
Bad Causes to produce such good Effects.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE To the HOUSE, Spoken by The STEP-MOTHER.
div.l: THe Ancient Britains I have pleas'd; and now
I come to their Descendents, to know how
You'l censure me; my Doom I fain would hear,
Yet, like you Lovers, what I hope, I fear.
But fear arrives too late, the time is past;
No going lesse, when once the Dice are cast,
Whether I fairly passe, or have thrown out,
You are to judge; pray, put me out of doubt.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE TO THE KING.
div.l: HAppy were those who English Playes first writ,
They flourish'd in the golden times of Wit;
Ripe Harvests then from Old and Modern Scenes
Th' Industrious Poet reap'd, but now he gleans:
In that kind Age every one prais'd all Playes,
No mercy's in the Criticks of our dayes.
The Authour knew these Disadvantages,
Yet ventur'd, hoping his desire to please;
May Royall Pitty move: You represent
That Pow'r, which for the act accepts th' intent.
